column16: 'shell'];"One of the only facilities in the world that uses carbon capture and storage technology to reduce the emissions of hydrogen production has the same carbon footprint as 1.2 million petrol cars
column17: according to a new report seen exclusively by Sky News.

column1: In a first-of-its-kind investigation into the plant
column2: which is owned and operated by Shell
column3: the lobby group Global Witness claims that it has emitted far more greenhouse gas than it has captured.

column1: While it has prevented five million tons of carbon dioxide from escaping into the atmosphere since 2015
column2: it has released a further 7.5 million tons
column3: the group said.

column1: Using carbon capture and storage (CCS) alongside hydrogen production is known as 'blue hydrogen' and has been much championed by governments and the energy industry alike as vital to the green transition.
Image: Shell has dismissed the claims made by Global Witness
column2: saying its analysis is 'simply wrong'

column1: Although Shell publishes its broader emissions annually and reports these site specific emissions in technical reports to Canadian authorities
column2: they have not been included in any public-focused communications
column3: which report authors say amounts to Shell ""not telling us the full story.""

column1: Advertisement
The plant in question is located in Alberta
column2: Canada and is part of Shell's Scotford refinery
column3: where hydrogen is produced for use in refining bitumen - a type of oil sands.

column1: 'Quest'
column2: the CCS facility
column3: was added in 2015 as part of a project to test the capabilities of the new technology.

column1: As Quest was
column2: in effect
column3: 'retrofitted' to an existing plant
column4: it doesn't cover the emissions from the entire facility.

column1: Experts say that more modern
column2: 'purpose built'
column3: blue hydrogen facilities can capture over 90% of a plant's emissions.

column1: The report found that this facility captures just 48% of its on-site carbon dioxide emissions.
Once you include other emissions
column2: such as from the fossil gas supply chain
column3: only 39% are captured.

column1: Despite this
column2: the plant has been subsidised by the Canadian government to the tune of $US654m.

column1: Image: The Scotford refinery began operations in 1984. Pic: Shell
Shell says that its carbon capture system at this project in Canada is an effective tool for reducing carbon emissions.
Our investigation found that's clearly not the case
column2: said Dominic Eagleton
column3: senior campaigner and report author at Global Witness.

column1: Carbon capture is definitely part of the problem. Because it has a history of failure
column2: almost 80% of government funded large scale
column3: carbon capture projects have failed over the years.

column1: Instead of investing in this dirty
column2: climate-wrecking fuel
column3: governments should promote and boost investment into renewable energy sources like wind power
column5: that can take us to a genuinely more sustainable future and a safe climate for all.""

column1: Hydrogen production has existed for many years
column2: but it has become a popular fuel amid the push to net zero as it emits no greenhouse gasses at the point of consumption.

column1: Please use Chrome browser for a more accessible video player 1:34 All aboard the UK's first hydrogen-powered train
However
column2: it is predominantly produced using fossil fuels in a process that emits greenhouse gas - this is dubbed 'grey hydrogen'.

column1: While there are a few examples of it being produced using renewable energy ('green hydrogen')
column2: at present this is much more expensive.

column1: 'Blue hydrogen' has therefore been touted as a good solution in the immediacy
column2: as it is a cleaner technology that can be scaled quickly and comparatively cheaply.

column1: There are only a handful of facilities globally that use CCS with hydrogen production and there are none which currently deploy the most modern 'gold standard' purpose-built technology.
This newer technology is being designed to capture emissions from all stages of the hydrogen production process and not just a section of it
column2: as is seen at the moment. Experts say it could capture as much as 97%.

column1: Shell itself is planning to build such a facility at the Scotford refinery in a project called 'Polaris'.
Some sections of the energy industry argue that it is this technology that should properly constitute the definition of blue hydrogen.
A Shell spokesperson said of the report: ""This analysis is simply wrong. Our Quest facility was designed some years ago as a demonstration project to prove the underlying CCS concept
column2: while capturing around a third of CO2 emissions.

column1: Image: Shell is one of the companies investing in CCS as it targets investment towards a greener future

It is not a hydrogen production facility. The hydrogen projects we're planning - like Polaris - will use a new technology that captures more than 90% of emissions. Global Witness are comparing apples with pears.""
But independent experts say facilities like Shell's are examples of blue hydrogen and it is right we should learn lessons from the technology and heed warnings about the emissions.
I call it 'blue hydrogen mark one'"" explains Professor Nilay Shah
column2: head of department of chemical engineering at Imperial College London.

column1: Please use Chrome browser for a more accessible video player 21:29 Will energy price hikes threaten climate action?
If you capture what we call the 'process emissions' only you might be capturing roughly half the C02 emissions.
[But] It demonstrates how to go about many elements of the system. Not only capturing the carbon dioxide but also cleaning it up
column2: compressing it
column3: transporting it and storing it. And from that we can learn how to go to the much higher capture rates.""

column1: The debate over blue hydrogen is prescient because there are a number of plans underway to build facilities in the UK
column2: and blue hydrogen also has a central role in the UK government's strategy.

column1: All UK-based proposals plan to use the most modern iterations of this technology with high capture rates.
One of them
column2: led by energy firm Equinor
column3: plans to develop what it calls the UK's first ""at-scale"" blue hydrogen facility.

column1: Image: Equinor's plans for the site are expected to create tens of thousands of jobs. Pic: px Group
The project
column2: called Hydrogen to Humber Saltend (H2H Saltend)
column3: will provide the beginnings of a ""decarbonised industrial cluster"" in the Humber region and is part of a larger move to provide clean energy to vast swathes of industry in the North East.

column1: The project is also expected to create tens of thousands of jobs.
I think that we should be incredibly proud of these opportunities
column2: this will really create an international spotlight on these industrial regions
column3: explained Dan Sadler
column4: Equinor's UK VP for low carbon solutions.

column1: While critics say it is wrong to be investing in technology that still requires the burning of fossil fuels and the money would be better spent on scaling entirely renewable sources
column2: he argues blue hydrogen is a practical
column3: positive solution now.

column1: I think it's the right technology
column2: the right scale at the right time.

column1: What we need to be able to do is start the hydrogen economy and we need to start at a scale that can justify the infrastructure.""
You can't jump to utopia
column2: you have to step there. We may all agree that in the longer term an entirely self-sustaining green hydrogen market may be the ultimate panacea.

column1: But the reality is that the climate emergency is now
column2: we need to be making tangible impacts on climate change obligations.""

column1: Global Witness and others point out that carbon capture rates alone are not enough to assess the carbon footprint of any such sites as they don't include the emissions from the fossil gas supply chain and other related activities.

The UK government is set to introduce a 'low carbon hydrogen standard' to ensure that sites being developed are low emissions although the exact rate of that standard has yet to be decided.";https://web.archive.org/web/20220120171420/https://news.sky.com/story/climate-change-shell-carbon-capture-facility-secures-just-48-of-hydrogen-production-emissions-12520938;

column17: 'guardian'];"A dog in Hampshire has been rescued from rising tides with a sausage attached to a drone.

He said: ""We certainly would consider using sausages again: every dog and search operation is always going to be different

The maximum take-off weight of the drone had to be checked before attaching the sausage to it to make sure it would fly.
Once on higher ground
column2: Millie ran away a second time
column3: leaving her owner Emma Oakes worried once again for her safety.

column1: The pet was eventually found inland from the marsh and ran into the arms of her owner's father when she was found.
Ms Oakes
column2: a carehome owner
column3: told The Guardian: ""Relief just poured over me. It was just absolutely fantastic to have her home.""";https://web.archive.org/web/20220120171420/https://news.sky.com/story/dog-rescued-from-drowning-after-sausage-dangled-from-drone-in-hampshire-12520987;

column16: 'party'];"Bury South MP Christian Wakeford's defection from the Conservative Party to Labour has left voters questioning whether there will now be a by-election in his constituency.

column1: The MP was elected in 2019 to the Greater Manchester constituency with a slim majority of 402 in a seat that had been Labour since 1997.
His announcement that he was crossing the floor just before Prime Minister's Questions on Wednesday came as a shock to many
column2: but he is believed to have been in talks with the Opposition since October.

column1: Mr Wakeford said the ""partygate"" scandal confirmed his decision after ""many months"" of sleepless nights over the government's decisions
column2: from free schools meals and Universal Credit to the Owen Paterson affair and lockdown parties.

column1: His defection has raised questions over whether there will be a by-election but
column2: due to the rules it is unlikely.

column1: Advertisement
Image: Sir Keir Starmer welcomed Christian Wakeford to the Labour Party
Does an MP defecting automatically trigger a by-election?
No. There are no rules requiring a by-election if an MP crosses the floor.
Parliament acts on the electoral principle that people vote for individuals
column2: not parties.

column1: There still could be a by-election though
column2: as there is often pressure to call one when an MP defects.

column1: Tories calling for PM to resign 'facing intimidation and blackmail from party'
column2: MP says

column1: Does Labour
column2: Christian Wakeford's new party
column3: want a by-election?

column1: A Labour source told Sky News: ""There won't be a by-election"".
Shadow chancellor Rachel Reeves said she did not think there needed to be a by-election in Bury South but said ""bring on"" a general election.
She told Sky News: ""In the last parliament
column2: when Labour MPs left the party and joined other parties
column3: formed new parties
column4: there weren't by-elections in those constituencies.

column1: Indeed
column2: I wasn't calling for by-elections then but when elected as an MP it is your name people put a cross against.

column1: Christian Wakeford stood in Bury South
column2: people put a cross against his name as they did against my name in Leeds West.""

column1: Please use Chrome browser for a more accessible video player 0:53 Cheers as Tory MP defects to Labour
But other parts of the Labour Party think there should be a by-election
column2: with the left-wing section Momentum calling for one as they do not think Mr Wakeford should be in the party.

column1: Joshua Harcup
column2: youth officer for Bury South's Labour Party
column3: is pushing for Mr Wakeford to call a by-election as it is ""about democracy"".

column1: He told Sky News: ""I think it's positive that he's changed his mind but as you can see from some of the Whatsapp messages leaked yesterday
column2: he's made some comments which are abusive about the Labour Party.

column1: I would like him to apologise. He would not get my support as our candidate as he doesn't share Labour values.""
History shows by-elections after a defection are a huge risk Tamara Cohen Political correspondent @tamcohen Defections are very rare
column2: and the MP who ""crosses the floor"" often ends up mistrusted by their old colleagues and new comrades. Holding a by-election is not required
column3: unless the MP decides to do so. This precedent was set in 2014 when Tory MPs Douglas Carswell and Mark Reckless defected in quick succession to UKIP and both held their seats in by-elections. But it's a huge risk and arguably stopped others joining them. None of the famous Tory to Labour defectors – pro-EU Tory Quentin Davies to Labour in 2007
column4: Alan Howarth to Labour on the eve of its conference in 1995 in a blow to John Major
column6: a Tory shadow minister to New Labour in 1999
column7: held by-elections. Tory cabinet ministers are publicly calling for a by-election
column8: but with a majority of 402 in a seat held by Labour since 1997
column9: senior figures privately concede it's not a contest they are eager for.

column1: Do the Conservatives want a by-election?
Yes.

column19: 'gays'];"Tinder is charging young gay and lesbian users and people over 30 more for its premium service
column20: according to an investigation by Which?

column1: The watchdog says its research could suggest discrimination by the dating app and a breach of UK law.

Which? asked almost 200 mystery shoppers to create real profiles and make a note of prices quoted for Tinder Plus - a premium package with perks such as unlimited ""Likes"" and ""Rewinds"" and the ability to undo accidental selections.
It showed some gay and lesbian users were paying more
column2: with an average premium of more than 10% (£6.74) compared to bisexual users
column3: and more than 8% (£5.28) compared to heterosexual users.

column1: Image: Tinder said the price difference was 'a discount for younger users'
This trend was driven by the youngest age group
column2: with Which? finding that gay and lesbian people aged 18 to 29 paid £60.15 on average - 37% more than heterosexual users aged under 30 (who paid £44.06 on average) and 30% more than bisexual users under 30 (£46.09).

column1: Advertisement
When it came to age
column2: those in the 30 to 49-year-old age bracket paid 48% more - a £24 difference - and the over-50s paid 46% more - a £23.19 difference - on average for a 12-month Tinder Plus subscription.

column1: Which? said it had reported its findings to the Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) and the Information Commissioner's Office.
The group's director of policy and advocacy
column2: Rocio Concha
column3: said the research suggested ""unlawful price discrimination""
column4: whether or not it is intentional on Tinder's part
column5: and potentially unlawful processing of personal data.

column1: If regulators decide that Tinder's personalised pricing is breaking the law
column2: then the dating app giant must face strong action.""

column1: Tinder said it was ""categorically untrue that our pricing structure discriminates in any way by sexual preference"".
It told Which? that older people did have to pay more in some countries
column2: but said the price difference was ""a discount for younger users"".

column1: The Equality Act 2010 makes it unlawful to charge people of one sexual orientation more than others unless there is a clear justification for this.
The consumer group noted that it was occasionally justifiable under UK law to offer age-based price variations for the same product or service
column2: such as discounts to over-65s or students
column3: where it can be shown there is a legitimate basis for this.

column1: However
column2: it said that in the case of Tinder it was unclear as to why over-30s were paying more.

column1: What has Tinder said about the claims?
A Tinder spokeswoman told Which?: ""Tinder is free to use and the vast majority of our members enjoy our app without upgrading to the paid experience.
However
column2: we do offer a variety of subscription options to help our members stand out and match with new people more efficiently.

column1: Tinder operates a global business and
column2: in some geographies
column3: we offer discounted subscriptions to younger members.

column1: In addition
column2: we frequently offer promotional rates which can vary based on factors like location or length of subscription. No other demographic information is considered in our pricing structure.""

column1: An EHRC spokeswoman said: ""As Britain's equality regulator it is our job to protect
column2: uphold and enforce equality laws. We take reports of discrimination very seriously.

column1: This report of potential discrimination by Tinder is concerning. We will consider these findings by Which? and respond in due course.""";https://web.archive.org/web/20220121041004/http://news.sky.com/story/tinder-charges-more-for-young-gays-lesbians-and-over-30s-claims-which-12521152;

column20: 'unites'];"It's known as the knife crime capital of London.

column1: The people of Croydon hate this label - and they're doing everything they can to get rid of it.
But there's a reason for this unwanted reputation.
Grim rollcall of young victims killed in capital this year
Image: Youth worker Anthony King organised the event to send a message to young people
Last year was the worst on record for teenage murders in London. There were 30 in total
column2: and five happened in Croydon - more than any other borough in the capital.

column1: Advertisement
But the community is fighting back. The killings have sparked the birth of a new movement.
A group of more than 100 community members - including youth workers
column2: schools
column3: the Met and local politicians - have united to tackle knife crime in the area.

column1: Image: Jermaine Cools
column3: was stabbed to death in November 2021

column1: Croydon
column2: this has to stop!"" Anthony King's booming voice echoes around the streets of his home town.

column1: The youth worker has organised a march to send a message to the young people. Hundreds join him to march through the main strip of shops.
Anthony tells me: ""We're here to send the youth a message - that we're here for you. We need mothers to stop the narrative that there's no men in our communities.
There are men in our communities and there are men that want to stop the knife crime. The parents in this community should stop and search their children before the Met do.
I'm working with the Met
column2: look at my skin colour. I will stand with the Met until we've got this problem dealt with.""

column1: Image: Jermaine's father Julius Cools says 'it has to stop now'
The march passed the spot in London Road where 14-year-old Jermaine Cools was stabbed to death in November 2021.
His father
column2: Julius Cools
column3: strokes his picture at the scene as the procession passes.

column1: Julius tells me: ""Jermaine was our life - he meant everything to us. My son lost his life
column2: and the boy who killed him has lost his too
column3: because he's in prison now.

column1: There's no end to this. It has to stop now.""
Image: Tilisha Goupall says she is 'scared to have kids'
I also meet Tilisha Goupall
column2: whose 15-year-old brother Jermaine was stabbed to death in Croydon in 2017.

column1: These young kids don't understand the impact of carrying a knife. I can't put into words how this has affected my family. I don't want anyone to go through what we've been through.""
She added: ""I'm scared to have kids. If I have a child
column2: is my child going to get stabbed? Am I going to have to go through that trauma again? Because of what's happening now - with all the teenagers dying.

column1: Am I going to have to raise a child only to know that one day they'll be killed? That's a trauma I don't want.""
Image: Jermaine Goupall
column3: was stabbed to death in Croydon in 2017

column1: After her brother's death
column2: Tilisha launched the Justice for Jermaine Foundation to educate young people about the impact of carrying knives.

column1: The march was part of a concerted effort to take the youths off the streets and out of the clutches of gangs.

One of the many organisations involved is United to Change and Inspire (UTCAI). Its co-founder Troy Davis said: ""The reason for the violence comes down to many things - you just have to look at the economics.
Image: Troy Davis is the co-founder of United to Change and Inspire (UTCAI)
The first thing that is going to be cut is the thing that affects young people
column2: so when you take away hope - what do you think is going to happen? Of course
column3: it's going to spiral out of control.

column1: And that's what we're here to do - to provide opportunities for the young people here and making sure that they progress in society.""
The combined efforts to combat knife crime in Croydon include ex-gang members. I was invited to meet Jay Jay
column2: who has mentored more than 1
column3: 000 youths in the area.

column1: Image: Jay Jay has mentored more than 1
column2: 000 young people in the area

column1: He was working with a teenager who has recently turned his back on gangs.
He told me: ""I got involved in selling drugs
column2: carrying knives
column3: getting involved in gangs. But me going through all that gave me a first-hand insight into how our youth think.

column1: It makes it much easier to get through to these kids. They're much more likely to engage with me because they know I've lived it - I've been to prison and turned my life around.""
Image: Munir: 'It's terrifying - anything can happen at any time'
His mentee Munir says Jay Jay saved his life.

Munir said: ""Life on the street makes no sense. It's terrifying - anything can happen at any time. I just want every youth to take a moment for themselves and ask what you're doing with your life.""";https://web.archive.org/web/20220121041004/http://news.sky.com/story/croydon-this-has-to-stop-community-unites-to-rid-itself-of-being-londons-knife-crime-capital-12521069;

column20: an unknown number of whom will have died without receiving what they were owed

column1: The Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) estimates it has underpaid 134
column2: 000 pensioners
column3: mostly women
column4: over £1bn of their state pension entitlement
column5: with some errors dating as far back as 1985.

column1: In January 2021
column2: DWP started an exercise to correct the errors - the ninth such exercise since 2018
column3: the Public Accounts Committee (PAC) said.

column1: Dame Meg Hillier
column2: chairwoman of the PAC
column3: said: ""Departments that make errors through maladministration have a duty to put those it wronged back in the position they should have been

column1: Image: The handling of the crisis has been described as a 'shameful shambles'
In reality DWP can never make up what people have actually lost
column2: over decades
column3: and in many cases it's not even trying.

column1: Advertisement
An unknown number of pensioners died without ever getting their due and there is no current plan to pay back their estates.
DWP is now on its ninth go at fixing these mistakes since 2018
column2: the specialised staff diverted to fix this mess costing tens of millions more to the taxpayer and predictable consequences in delays to new pension claims.

column1: And there is no assurance that the errors that led to these underpayments in the first place will not be repeated in the correction exercise.
This is a shameful shambles.""
The errors mostly affect widows
column2: divorcees and women who rely on their husband's pension contributions for some of their pension.

column1: Complex pension rules and a reliance on highly manual systems led to the underpayments.
The committee of MPs said the underlying IT system relied on to manage millions of pensioner records dates back to 1988.
Quality checks failed to identify the systematic underpayments and small errors added up over years to significant sums of money.
The PAC said the department should consider whether there are cost-effective ways to upgrade its IT systems ""as a matter of urgency"".
How much will it cost to fix the errors?
There is currently no formal plan for contacting the next of kin where a pensioner who was underpaid is dead
column2: the committee said.

column1: The DWP is only paying those it has identified as having a legal entitlement to arrears
column2: in some cases many years after the event
column3: and has been inconsistent in paying interest

column1: Women on pensions as low as £1 a week could be owed 'lottery winning' sums
It has also shown little interest in understanding the further knock-on consequences
column2: including on social care provision
column3: for those it underpaid

column1: Fixing DWP's mistakes comes at great cost to the taxpayer and is expected to cost £24.3 in staff costs alone by the end of 2023
column2: the PAC added.

column1: It also said the department should be treating state pension underpayments as seriously as overpayments.";https://web.archive.org/web/20220121041004/http://news.sky.com/story/pension-scandal-long-term-underpayment-of-thousands-is-a-shameful-shambles-says-group-of-mps-12520971;

column21: 'sales'];"Retail sales suffered their worst December slump on record last month as the Omicron variant was blamed for keeping shoppers away.

column1: The 3.7% month-on-month decline in sales volumes reported by the Office for National Statistics (ONS) follows a strong November
column2: when some consumers chose to make Christmas purchases early.

column1: A fall in demand for petrol and diesel
column2: due to more people working from home under Plan B rules
column3: also contributed to the slump.

column1: Live COVID updates from the UK and around the world
Please use Chrome browser for a more accessible video player 2:18 Omicron impacts business
It was significantly worse than the 0.6% drop that had been pencilled in by forecasters and was the biggest December decline on records going back to 1996.
Advertisement
The fall was also the worst for any month since last January when Britain was coming under a tough new lockdown.
It highlighted the pressure on businesses created by the Omicron variant - and restrictions designed to tackle its spread - over the key festive season.

They will be now hoping for a boost as the Plan B rules are lifted - though separate figures published on Friday by GfK show a sharp drop in consumer confidence blamed on the surge in the cost of living.
The ONS data showed that in December
column2: retail sales even failed to match last year's COVID-hit festive period
column3: charting a 0.9% year-on-year decline.

column1: Heather Bovill

column3: said: ""After strong pre-Christmas trading in November
column4: retail sales fell across the board in December
column5: with feedback from retailers suggesting Omicron impacted on footfall.""

The figures showed that fashion stores saw an 8% decline and department stores dropped 6.3%

column1: Online sales were slightly higher as a proportion of the total
column3: than they were in November

column1: For 2021 as a whole
column2: retail sales were up by 5.1% - a level of growth that has not been higher since 2002.

column1: However that follows a 1.8% decline in 2020 when the pandemic took hold. Compared with 2019
column2: annual retail sales last year were up by a more modest 3.2%.

column1: Bethany Beckett
column2: UK economist at Capital Economics
column3: said the retail sales data added to evidence of Omicron dragging on GDP in December.

column1: She added: ""With encouraging signs that the Omicron outbreak may have turned a corner and the government's Plan B restrictions due to be lifted next week
column2: retail sales may recoup a bit of this fall in January and probably all of it in February and March.

column2: with the UK's cost of living crisis looming
column3: we expect a weakening in the consumer recovery to dampen retail sales further ahead.""

column1: Some experts have said it's possible the sub-lineage could spread quicker than 'original' Omicron.

Analysis: Something to keep an eye on - but no cause for panic Tom Clarke Science and technology editor @aTomClarke Could the timing be any worse? A new ""sub-lineage"" of Omicron coming along just as the government abandons all COVID restrictions. But while BA.2. is definitely something to be keeping an eye on
column2: it’s not one to worry about too much based on what we know so far. BA.2 has been circulating in the UK for some time at a low level compared with the dominant type of Omicron here (BA.1). In parts of India and the Philippines it is the major version of Omicron. In previous waves there have been big regional differences in what sub-lineage of a particular variant is more
column3: or less dominant. The reason it's been elevated to a ""variant under investigation"" is because of what's happening in Denmark. Yesterday
column4: Danish officials announced the BA.2 sub-lineage now accounted for nearly 50% of cases in Denmark (up from just 20% at Christmas). What's more
column5: the BA.1. version of Omicron and the Delta variant are on their way down in the country. Denmark also finds itself in a spectacular surge in COVID-19 cases. It's good evidence
column7: that the BA.2. might be more infectious than BA.1. The question scientists in Denmark are trying to answer is whether case numbers are surging there because of the BA.2 lineage or would have done whichever flavour of Omicron it might be. The feeling among virologists is that BA.2 can't be that much more infectious than BA.1 because if it was
column8: we'd likely have seen it rapidly replace BA.1. in places like the UK. Yet we've seen a very small number of cases. For that reason it's unlikely to lead to a significant new wave of cases here – the difference between Omicron BA.1. and BA.2. is nothing like the difference between Delta and Omicron. Another reason we shouldn't be too concerned is that evidence from Denmark and India shows no evidence of increased severity of illness with BA.2 compared to BA.1. And while BA.1 is genetically different from BA.2
column9: it is not anticipated it will be much better at avoiding antibodies from vaccines or previous infections. The worst that might happen is BA.2 gradually replaces BA.1 in the UK and makes the downward slope of our Omicron wave that little bit longer. But if COVID-19 has taught us anything it's to assume nothing and wait for the evidence. So watch this space.

column1: Consistent growth across multiple countries is evidence BA.2 may be some degree more transmissible than BA.1

column1: Unfortunately this is really where the evidence mostly ends - we do not currently have a strong handle on antigenicity
column2: severity or much evidence for how much more transmissibility BA.2 might have over BA.1 - however we can make some guesses/early observations.""

column20: 'diplomats'];"Tensions continue to boil in eastern Europe
column21: as the threat of a Russian invasion in Ukraine continues to draw international attention.

column1: On Thursday
column2: US President Joe Biden warned that ""Russia will pay a heavy price"" if it invades Ukraine
column3: while Russia announced naval drills in several parts of the world and claimed the West is plotting ""provocations"" in Ukraine.

column1: In an attempt to ease tensions
column2: the top diplomats from Washington and the Kremlin are set for crunch talks in Geneva.

column1: What does America want from the talks?
US Secretary of State Antony Blinken is preparing to meet his Russian counterpart
column2: foreign minister Sergei Lavrov
column3: however the former indicated that talks will likely fail.

column1: Advertisement
Ahead of the meeting
column2: Mr Blinken said on Thursday: ""These are difficult issues we are facing and resolving them won't happen quickly.""

column1: America wants one thing above all.

To get this settled without a Russian invasion of Ukraine so Washington can move attention eastwards. Joe Biden sees China as a much bigger threat and challenge than Russia and wants to focus attention in that direction.
Image: US Secretary of State
column2: Antony Blinken (left)
column3: and Russia's Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov will hold talks in Geneva on Friday

column1: Barack Obama felt the same
column2: wanting a pivot to the east
column3: but events have a way of interfering in international affairs and the middle east and Syria especially kept sucking his attention back in.

column1: Mr Biden wants to avoid the same with Ukraine and Russia.
But President Biden knows the two are linked
column2: that missteps over Ukraine will complicate matters over China.

column1: Chinese President Xi Jinping is watching intently.
If Russia can ride roughshod over the West in Ukraine
column2: the Chinese may be emboldened over Taiwan
column3: which Xi Jinping wants absorbed into the Chinese mainland.

column1: Image: The United Kingdom has sent defensive weapons to Ukraine
So the Biden administration has worked hard to deter Russia
column2: assiduously trying to build unity and resolve among its allies on sanctions it hopes will be enough to avert invasion.

column1: A carrot and stick approach
The sanctions are largely financial and economic but critics say that is like bringing a knife to a gunfight.
Please use Chrome browser for a more accessible video player 0:32 Joe Biden said that Russia will be met with 'severe' economic response if it invades
Washington hopes the carrot and stick approach will be effective.
The stick being the threat of sanctions
column2: the carrot talks on issues Russia wants aired.

column1: America is prepared to talk about transparency
column2: better communication between NATO and Russia
column3: arms reductions
column5: hoping that will assuage Russian fears about NATO's inexorable expansion to the east.

column1: Image: The US has warned the Kremlin it will face 'heavy' sanctions if it invades Ukraine
On the face of it that is not nearly enough to meet Russia's demands for sweeping security guarantees.
But US negotiators hope there is enough to chew on while more and more military materiel is sent to Ukraine and while the window for invasion passes.
Come mid-February some military experts say the ground will be too soft for the movement of Russian heavy armour.
The Russians want to see written responses to their demands.
Please use Chrome browser for a more accessible video player 4:26 Ukraine has borders with a series of NATO members
column2: all of whom fear a Russian attack on their neighbour

column1: What does Russia want from the talks?
Today's high-level meeting in Geneva is unlikely to yield any major breakthroughs but at least the sides are still talking.
Russia's core demand
column2: that NATO's open door policy be shut once and for all and that any promise of future membership for Ukraine and Georgia be revoked is the one issue where NATO has made clear it won't budge.

column1: The more Russia threatens
column2: the more likely it is that Russia's other core grievance
column3: the provision of Western military support to Ukraine
column4: will intensify further. That is a considerable diplomatic impasse.

column1: Whatever might be said on other issues of strategic security
column2: the US missile defence systems in Poland and Romania for example which are long-standing grievances for Russia
column3: are secondary and were under discussion before Russia started its troop build-up. Concessions there are unlikely to cut through.

column1: Image: President Joe Biden
NATO's promise of possible future accession to Ukraine and Georgia is in any case entirely academic. It will not happen anytime soon and both sides know that. Perhaps
column2: if appeasement of sorts is a strategy the US will countenance
column3: it is best to say that out loud.

column1: The Russian stance that this is a complete package
column2: take it or leave it
column3: is a maximalist position and in any case Russia's foreign ministry has said it wants written responses to each proposal
column4: (which Mr Blinken has already said he will not be giving)
column5: which would suggest they will consider the issues separately.

column1: The question is: What is Vladimir Putin's ultimate goal? Even his own diplomats may not know. Will he be content with concessions around the edges of his security guarantee proposals or is diplomacy a side-bar in an inevitable slide to conflict? Is his prize to squeeze concessions from NATO
column2: to downgrade Ukraine's defensive capabilities (which he could do with missile attacks without even sending troops across the border) or is it about Russia's place in the world - reasserting a Russian sphere of influence and ensuring Ukraine remains a buffer between Russia and the West? Or is it a more emotional pitch where Ukraine itself is the prize
column3: wrenched as he sees it from the Motherland after the collapse of the Soviet Union?

column1: Mr Putin may not be on some grand imperialist campaign but he does feel the loss of great power status keenly and he does believe in spheres of influence. Even now
column2: with Europe on high alert
column3: he has the whole world talking about him.

column1: The US President's incursion vs invasion slip is perhaps of relatively little consequence. Russia knows Europe is not united on its response
column2: especially when it comes to hybrid warfare tactics which don't involve actual military invasion. Russia has also never been swayed by the punishment
column3: it has workshopped all possible sanctions scenarios and they have not deterred it before; it is swayed by the prize. The prize that only Mr Putin knows. That's what makes diplomacy so hard.";https://web.archive.org/web/20220121153351/https://news.sky.com/story/russia-ukraine-tensions-top-diplomats-from-us-and-russia-set-for-crunch-talks-in-geneva-but-what-do-both-countries-want-12521366;

column20: 'mild'];"Could the timing be any worse? A new ""sub-lineage"" of Omicron coming along just as the government abandons all COVID restrictions.

column1: But while BA.2 is definitely something to be keeping an eye on
column2: it's not one to worry about too much based on what we know so far.

column1: BA.2 has been circulating in the UK for some time at a low level compared to the dominant type of Omicron here (BA.1.)
In parts of India and the Philippines it is the major version of Omicron. In previous waves there have been big regional differences in what sub-lineage of a particular variant is more
column2: or less dominant.

column1: The reason it's been elevated to a ""variant under investigation"" is because of what's happening in Denmark.
Advertisement
Please use Chrome browser for a more accessible video player 14:48 Debate: Should COVID rules be relaxed?
COVID latest: Follow live updates from the UK and around the world
Yesterday
column2: Danish officials announced the BA.2 sub-lineage now accounted for nearly 50% of cases in Denmark (up from just 20% at Christmas).

column1: What's more the BA.1. version of Omicron
column2: and the Delta variant are on their way down in the country. Denmark also finds itself in a spectacular surge in COVID-19 cases.

column1: It's good evidence
column2: though not proof
column3: that the BA.2 might be more infectious than BA.1.

column1: The question scientists in Denmark are trying to answer is whether case numbers are surging there because of the BA.2 lineage or would have done whichever flavour of Omicron it might be.
Omicron 'sub-lineage' BA.2 designated as COVID variant under investigation
column2: says UKHSA

column1: The feeling among virologists is that BA.2 can't be that much more infectious than BA.1 because if it was
column2: we'd likely have seen it rapidly replace BA.1 in places like the UK. Yet we've seen a very small number of cases.

column1: For that reason it's unlikely to lead to a significant new wave of cases here - the difference between Omicron BA.1. and BA.2 is nothing like the difference between Delta and Omicron.

Another reason we shouldn't be too concerned is that evidence from Denmark and India shows no evidence of increased severity of illness with BA.2 compared to BA.1. And while BA.1 is genetically different from BA.2
column2: it is not anticipated it will be much better at avoiding antibodies from vaccines or previous infections.

column1: The worst that might happen is BA.2 gradually replaces BA.1 in the UK and makes downward slope of our Omicron wave that little bit longer. But if COVID-19 has taught us anything it's to assume nothing and wait for the evidence. So watch this space.";https://web.archive.org/web/20220121164123/https://news.sky.com/story/covid-19-the-omicron-sub-lineage-appears-to-be-mild-but-the-pandemic-has-taught-us-to-assume-nothing-12521918;

column20: 'film'];"Meat Loaf - real name Michael Lee Aday - has died aged 74.

column1: But how did a man named after a minced-meat dish become one of the most recognisable and significant musical and cultural figures in the world?
Sky News analysis of the data behind his career shows why his status as an icon will live on when the night is over
column2: when the morning comes and for years to come.

column1: He sold more than 100 million records during his 54-year career
column2: and his first Bat Out Of Hell album
column3: released in 1977
column4: spent more than 10 years in the Official Albums Charts.

column1: That places him ninth on the all-time list and fourth
column2: behind only Fleetwood Mac
column3: Pink Floyd and Oasis
column4: if you exclude greatest hits albums.

column1: Advertisement
I'd Do Anything For Love (But I Won't Do That)
column2: spent seven weeks at number one in the UK in 1993 and also topped charts in a further 27 countries.

column1: The album version of the song lasts more than 12 minutes - longer than Taylor Swift's recent record-breaker All Too Well (Ten Minute Version). It has been played more than 21 million times on Spotify.
The 'short' version
column3: has been played more than 120 million times.

column1: But as with so many of the biggest cultural icons
column2: he wasn't restricted to music.

column1: He also has 108 acting credits to his name
column2: including the Oscar-nominated Fight Club
column3: The Rocky Horror Picture Show and the 1997 Spice Girls film

column1: Fellow music-and-acting crossover star Will Smith has just 74 credits
column2: while despite limiting their careers to film alone
column3: Leonardo Di Caprio and Meryl Streep have 46 and 94 respectively

column1: Robert De Niro has slightly more - with 125 - but beating two out of three of the biggest names in Hollywood history ain't bad.
And his fame didn't end with the age of social media. There are 26 million Google results for a meme in which people suggested what he wouldn't do for love.
He clearly embraced this newfound notoriety among younger fans.
My friend interviewed Meat Loaf about ten years ago and he graciously signed a printed-out meme for me. A king. pic.twitter.com/ZmvRSxuViU — Caitlin Welsh (@Caitlin_Welsh) January 21
At Meat Loaf's peak it could be said that wherever you were and wherever you went
column2: there was always gonna be someone with his face emblazoned on a T-shirt.

column1: There are now more than 500 active listings for Meat Loaf memorabilia on Amazon and eBay.
One of the products Meat lent his name to was Veg
column2: as part of a vegan food campaign by Frankie & Benny's.

column1: He didn't take on the restaurant's suggestion of a rebrand to Veg Loaf
column2: but was a vegetarian for 11 years as part of a diet that saw him lose 5st (32kg)
column3: from his 19st (120kg) peak.

column1: Like a bat out of hell
column2: Meat Loaf the man may be gone
column3: gone
column4: gone - but his legacy is far from over.

column22: 'party'];"A former Conservative MP said a government whip threatened to pull funding for a major link road around Bath if he rebelled against a Brexit vote.

column1: Ben Howlett
column2: MP for Bath from 2015-2017
column3: revealed the incident following senior Tory William Wragg telling the Commons he has been told of claims MPs who want Boris Johnson ousted have been intimidated and even blackmailed by the whips.

column1: Mr Howlett told Sky News: ""I was campaigning as a marginal constituency MP for a project
column2: it was a link road and people remember that in my constituency I was trying to get government funding for it and of course during the Brexit rebellions.

column1: The whipping operation involved me being told by a whip that if I ended up rebelling and continuing to rebel then I would lose out funding for that particular scheme
column2: which was frankly outrageous at the time.""

column1: He claimed the road would have reduced pollution and congestion in central Bath
column2: where some areas have nitrogen dioxide levels above safe limits.

column1: Advertisement

Please use Chrome browser for a more accessible video player 1:00 'Blackmailing by whips isn't something I've heard of'
Underhand tactics from whips 'been going on for years'
Mr Howlett said he was a new MP at the time but had the support of some senior Tories which meant he received some helpful advice on how to deal with threats from whips.
He added: ""The advice I received at the time is 'nonsense
column2: whips can't do that' and I was very good friends with the transport minister at the time so I could easily speak to the transport minister and say 'look this is what has happened' and of course
column3: they allayed any fears.""

column1: The former MP said those types of tactics ""have been going on for years"" so he is ""surprised"" the government is dismissing claims from current MPs about blackmail and intimidation.
Read more: Boris Johnson recovers his bounce as he vows to fight for his job
What do whips do? Each party appoints MPs
column2: who must be party loyalists
column3: to help organise and guide parliamentary business - these are the whips. The term ""whip"" comes from hunting etymology where a ""whipper-in"" whips the hounds to keep them from straying from the pack. One of their responsibilities is to make sure the maximum number of their MPs vote
column4: and vote the way their party wants to get government business through parliament. They are charged with promoting the leadership's agenda
column6: and are a go-between for the two. How whips encourage MPs to vote the way the government wants is often secretive
column7: but can involve them offering time off
column9: trips abroad and even a better - or worse - office. The whip can be removed from all of a party's MPs so they have a free vote. A three-line whip
column10: where a vote on a weekly email is underlined three times
column11: means an MP has to attend and vote the way the government wants. MPs can have the whip withdrawn
column12: which means they are expelled from the party so remain an MP but are independent as they are no longer expected to follow the whip.

column1: MPs considering releasing damning recording of chief whip
A group of 2019 intake Conservative MPs are reportedly thinking about releasing text messages and even a recording with the chief whip making threats.
One of the MPs told the Times: ""They pulled me over and I told them I was voting against them.
They got right up in my face. They told me that if you think you're getting a single f***ing penny
column2: forget it. If you think a minister is coming to your patch forget it. You're done.""

column1: Mr Howlett said the evidence ""will end up coming out"" but added: ""An ex-whip told me earlier on today the first rule of whipping is don't leave any evidence so it seems like they have left a cookie crumb trail.""
Christian Wakeford
column2: the MP who defected from the Conservatives to Labour this week
column3: claimed whips threatened to pull funding for a school in his area if he did not vote with the government on free school meals during COVID.

column1: Please use Chrome browser for a more accessible video player 4:20 Will there be a leadership challenge and how would it work?

Some Conservative MPs have expressed their surprise that whips would threaten MPs.
Fay Jones
column2: an MP first elected in 2019
column3: told Sky News the threat Mr Howlett claimed to have had ""isn't an experience I've been through"".

column1: She told Sky News: ""The whips have been extremely fair to deal with
column2: easy to deal with.

column1: Their job is to get government business through but some of the reports that have been made and the allegations
column2: they really just don't ring true with me so I'm a bit confused to be honest.""

column1: Business Secretary Kwasi Kwarteng also said he did not recognise the claims made by MPs this week.

He told Sky News he was ""very surprised"" and it is not something ""I've ever heard of"" but said it should be investigated.";https://web.archive.org/web/20220121164123/https://news.sky.com/story/whip-threatened-to-pull-funding-for-link-road-around-bath-for-rebelling-on-brexit-ex-mp-claims-12521860;

column21: 'major'];"Fighting is continuing at the world's largest prison for IS fighters after an attempted breakout on Thursday
column22: in the most violent clashes since the defeat of its self-declared caliphate in 2019.

column1: Video from the scene shows smoke rising from Ghweiran prison in Syria and heavy exchanges of gunfire.
Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) in the Kurdish northeast of the country are battling to regain control of the jail after a car bomb exploded outside the walls on Thursday
column2: setting off a major riot inside.

column1: US forces in the country are helping to track down IS hideouts nearby using attack helicopters and air surveillance.
Among those killed were 20 soldiers and five civilians. Foreign fighters reportedly died too.
Image: The belongings of some Islamic State fighters. Pic: SDF via AP
Suicide car bomb was used
SDF commander Siamand Ali told Sky News: ""Dozens of IS fighters launched an attack on the prison.

They used a suicide car bomb which exploded at the front entrance of the prison. There was heavy fighting between prison security forces and IS fighters trying to enter the prison and from the surrounding area.
Counter terrorism forces and SDF managed to kill 25 IS fighters who launched the attack on the prison and more than 80 IS prisoners were arrested.""
Gunfire could still be heard almost 24 hours after the initial attack took place
column2: he added.

column1: Officially
column2: local authorities have denied that any IS fighters have escaped
column3: but the London-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights has said its sources believe ""dozens"" have fled.

column1: Sky sources in northeast Syria have reported dozens of families leaving the surrounding area
column2: frightened they will be caught up in the fighting or used as human shields by IS fugitives.

column1: There are also reports that a college campus near the prison has been seized by Islamic State.
The jail holds around three-and-a-half thousand IS prisoners and is one of many in the region housing former members of the group.
Image: Iraqi soldiers are still subject to attacks by Islamic State militants. File pic
Prisons overcrowded and inadequate
Kurdish forces have pleaded to the international community for help in securing the facilities but little assistance has been forthcoming
column2: leaving the prisons in a precarious position.

column1: Many are overcrowded and inadequate for holding violent terrorists; sporadic riots break out but are usually quickly crushed.
Last year
column2: a United Nations report estimated 10
column3: 000 Islamic State fighters were still free in Iraq and Syria and warned that the organisation is re-grouping.

column1: Sleeping soldiers murdered in Iraq
Meanwhile
column2: eleven Iraqi soldiers were killed in their sleep by Islamic State gunmen
column3: security officials said.

column1: The attack happened at 3am on Friday in al Azim district
column2: eastern Iraq
column3: officials told the AP news agency.

column1: IS militants broke into the barracks and murdered the sleeping soldiers in what was one of the deadliest attacks on the Iraqi military in recent months.
Reinforcements were reportedly sent to the village but no further details were given and there was no comment from the Iraqi military.
Islamic State was largely defeated in Iraq in 2017 but the group's militants continue to attack security forces
column2: and infrastructure such as power stations.

column1: In October the Sunni extremist group raided a mostly Shia village in Diyala province
column2: killing 11 civilians and injuring several others.

column1: According to officials
column2: the militants had been angry that their ransom demands for kidnapped villagers had not been met.

column1: The extremists have also increased their attacks in neighbouring Syria

column17: 'ukrainian'];"The US and UK have warned by Russia that it would ""pay a heavy price"" if it invades Ukraine.

column1: Tensions between Russia and the West are the worst they have been since the Cold War
column2: with UK Foreign Secretary Liz Truss claiming that an invasion would ""only lead to a terrible quagmire and loss of life"".

column1: Currently more than Russian 100
column2: 000 troops are stationed at various points along its border with Ukraine - a former Soviet state.

column1: Follow live updates as Russia and the US hold critical talks in Geneva
Please use Chrome browser for a more accessible video player 0:38 Truss: Kremlin 'dreams of re-creating the Soviet Union'
President Vladimir Putin and his officials insist they are just carrying out military exercises
column2: but fears of an invasion have been mounting since late last year when satellite imagery showed Russia sending more equipment and personnel.

column1: Advertisement
Here Sky News looks at what's happening on the Russian-Ukrainian border
column2: why tensions are so high and what it means for the West.

column1: What's the history between Russia and Ukraine?
Ukraine was part of the Russian empire for centuries before it became part of the USSR.
When the Soviet Union dissolved with the end of the Cold War in 1991
column2: Ukraine became independent.

column1: Although their shared history means the two are still very culturally linked
column2: Ukraine has sought to distance itself from Russia in recent years and instead look to the West for support.

column1: Image: A Ukrainian soldier stands in the trench on the line of separation from pro-Russian rebels
column2: in Mariupol
column3: Donetsk. Pic: AP

column1: By contrast
column2: Ukraine was a huge loss for Russia
column3: as it had the biggest population of all the former Soviet states to break away from Moscow.

column1: And with Vladimir Putin's rise to power
column2: the Kremlin has sought to regain influence and control over its former territories.

column1: This began with a more subtle approach in the early 2000s
column2: but when his favoured candidate in the 2004 Ukrainian election Viktor Yanukovych was ousted for rigging the result amid ""Orange Revolution"" protests in Kyiv
column3: things began to change.

column1: Image: Ukrainian forces are now being supported by the British. Pic: AP
Furious with the election of pro-Western opposition candidate Victor Yushchenko
column2: Mr Putin's approach became more aggressive.

column1: It culminated in Russia's illegal annexation of the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea in 2014.
Mr Yanukovych managed to gain power after five years of Mr Yushchenko in 2010 and served for four years.
But when the Kremlin-backed president rejected an association agreement with the EU in favour of bolstering relations with Moscow
column2: there were huge protests and he was ousted.

column1: Image: A convoy of Russian armoured vehicles moves along a highway in Crimea. Pic: AP
Russia's response was to annexe Crimea and declare it independent from Ukraine.
It also sent troops into the Ukrainian regions of Donetsk and Luhansk - an area known as Donbas - to support separatists who had been trying to break away from the country.
Fighting in Donbas
column2: which is near the Russian border
column3: has resulted in the death of more than 14

column1: France and Germany spearheaded a peace agreement between the two sides in 2015
column2: which helped end major conflicts
column3: but it failed to unite the two sides politically and small-scale tensions have continued since then.

column1: In early 2021 there had been increasing incidences of breaking the 2015 ceasefire
column2: which fuelled fears of a war
column3: but in April Moscow pulled back most of its troops and tensions lessened.

column1: Please use Chrome browser for a more accessible video player 3:23 On the frontline of Ukraine-Russia crisis
Where are troops stationed now?
Currently there are around 100
column2: 000 Russian troops stationed at various points along its 1
column3: 200-mile border with Ukraine.

column1: Last week US intelligence officials claimed that Russia is planning to deploy as many as 175
column2: 000 troops in preparation for a potential invasion that could happen early this year.

column1: Image: A map shows the numerous sites Russian troops are stationed at along the Ukrainian border

Most of Russia's military presence on the border is concentrated in the eastern breakaway provinces of Donetsk and Luhansk where its soldiers have been stationed in support of separatist rebels since 2014.
There has also been significant military presence to the north of Ukraine in areas such as Klintsy and Yelnya.
Satellite images from Yelnya
column2: which also borders Belarus
column3: in November 2021 showed Russia increasing its military presence
column4: which has fuelled fears a war could break out
column5: given its strategic location near the Ukrainian capital Kyiv.

column1: Image: Satellite images show Russian military presence on the eastern Ukrainian border. ©2022 Maxar Technologies
Aerial imagery has also revealed Russian military activity in areas north east of the Ukrainian border.
In November battle groups were seen training in Pogonovo before forces were pictured stationed at Soloti in December.
Tens of thousands of troops are also still stationed inside the annexed territory of Crimea
column2: with satellite images revealing significant Russian military deployments there in November last year.

column1: Ukrainian officials have repeatedly expressed concerns about Russian presence on the border
column2: while the Kremlin insists it is just military training.

column1: Image: More aerial images from the border
What does Russia want?
After rising to power in 2000
column2: Vladimir Putin has sought to maintain the Russian ""sphere of influence"" over its two neighbours and former Soviet states of Ukraine and Belarus.

column1: Any attacks on either state are seen by the president as a direct attack on Russian sovereignty.
He is also fearful of Western involvement in either resulting in a new democracy being established on the doorstep of Russia
column2: which has become increasingly autocratic during his rule.

column1: As such Russia has issued a list of demands that would reduce Western influence in the region.
Image: Russian President Vladimir Putin
It includes a guarantee that Ukraine would never become a member of NATO
column2: that the two end their security alliance
column3: and that numbers of NATO troops in eastern Europe are reduced.

column1: The US and other Western allies have described such demands as ""non-starters"" and completely unreasonable.
US Secretary of State Anthony Blinken has been taking part in crisis talks with Russian officials
column2: including foreign minister Sergey Lavrov
column3: this week in a bid de-escalate tensions.

column1: So far the West has indicated it would be prepared to compromise on how it carries out military exercises within the region and the location of missiles.
Image: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken (L) has been holding talks with Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov
What does Ukraine want?
Ukraine insists that Moscow cannot control whether it moves closer towards becoming a member of NATO or other Western alliances.
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has said Russia is trying to destabilise the country in a bid to oust him.
He says such a coup could come ahead of any potential military invasion.
Ukraine has also suffered a winter energy crisis after Russia imposed crippling sanctions on fuel imports.
How is the UK involved?
The UK has deployed 2
column2: 000 anti-tank missile launchers and 30 elite troops to help train the Ukrainian armed forces in the face of a potential fresh Russian invasion.

column1: An RAF C-17 transport plane has been seen flying back and forth between the UK and Ukraine since Monday
column2: according to flight-tracking software.

column1: Image: A British military cargo C-17 plane unloads anti-tank weapons in Ukraine
The weapons and personnel are being deployed as part of Operation Orbital
column2: the British training mission set up in Ukraine in 2015 following the annexation of Crimea.

column1: Defence Secretary Ben Wallace has stressed that British military presence in Ukraine is only for ""early-stage training"" and ""self-defence"".
They are not strategic weapons and pose no threat to Russia
column2: he said this week.

column1: They are to use in self-defence and the UK personnel providing the early-stage training will return to the UK after completing it.""
Image: British troops provide support to Ukrainian forces in the Kherson region of Ukraine on Thursday
A spokesperson for the Russian-UK ambassador said however: ""It is crystal clear that UK shipment of lethal weapons to Ukraine will only fuel the crisis.""
How could it affect relations with the West?
A fully-fledged conflict between Russia and Ukraine would have extreme consequences for international relations.
It would deepen hostilities between Moscow and the US
column2: the UK
column3: NATO and other Western member states.

column1: Speaking on a visit to Australia
column2: Liz Truss said: ""An invasion will only lead to a terrible quagmire and loss of life
column3: as we know from the Soviet-Afghan war and conflict in Chechnya.

column1: We need everyone to step up. Together with our allies
column2: we will continue to stand with Ukraine and urge Russia to de-escalate and engage in meaningful discussions.

column1: What happens in eastern Europe matters for the world.""
In December NATO secretary general Jens Stoltenberg threatened Russia with economic sanctions and ""political restrictions"".
He described the risk of an imminent invasion as a ""defining moment for European security"" and expressed his continued support of ""deterrence
column2: defence and combined dialogue"".";https://web.archive.org/web/20220121180958/https://news.sky.com/story/russia-ukraine-whats-happening-on-the-border-and-why-are-tensions-so-high-12521513;

column22: 'drivers'];"It is the early hours of the morning
column23: but this corner of Calais is busy
column24: just as it always is.

column1: At first
column2: you don't notice many of the people. Sure
column3: you see the blue flashing lights
column4: the police vans speeding around and the articulated lorries driving in and out. But in the shadows and the gloom
column5: there are hundreds of people milling around
column6: all waiting to try to hitch a lift to Britain.

column1: You see them as flashes of action. A lorry slows as it goes round a roundabout and suddenly there is a man sprinting alongside it. He reaches out his hands but can't quite pull himself up. The lorry speeds up again; the man slows up and walks away.
And so it happens again and again. Young men crouch in the shadows and then run out to try to pull themselves up on to a vehicle. Mostly they fail
column2: and skulk away. Sometimes they pull themselves on
column3: but are spotted by drivers
column4: who come to an angry halt.

column1: But occasionally they succeed. We watched one person
column2: with a blend of audacity
column3: agility and athleticism
column5: jump up and then pull himself into the space between cab and trailer.

column1: Advertisement
It is extremely dangerous. Just recently
column2: a teenager was killed after falling beneath the wheels of a lorry
column3: the latest in a line of fatalities. But for the people who throng around this area
column4: the risk is worth the potential reward. All these people are trying to get to Britain.

column1: Image: Migrants put their lives at risk by trying to hop on the back of lorries travelling to the UK
Crossing the Channel in a boat involves paying a people smuggler
column2: which can cost thousands of pounds
column3: as well as the significant chance that the boat will be overloaded
column5: break down or simply not turn up.

column1: Attempting to stow away on a lorry
column2: by contrast
column3: is free
column4: and the supply of suitable transport is more predictable. The lorry parks of Calais are full of vehicles crossing the Channel every day. The challenge is firstly to get on board

column1: Neither is easy
column2: which is why people often spend months on end attempting to get to Britain this way. And that's why
column3: on this cold
column5: the police are playing a cat and mouse game with all these migrants.

column1: When a police van arrives in one place
column2: the men go somewhere else and wait for the van to move on. No sooner has it left than the men return. It is a pattern that you see again and again.

column1: Even when they are caught on the back of lorries
column2: the police's powers to detain would-be stowaways are limited. Very rarely do even the most aggrieved of lorry drivers want to press charges. By and large
column3: the drivers just want to get on with their journey.

column1: So lorry drivers
column2: migrants and police officers find themselves in an elaborate night-time choreography. A battle of wits and experience.

column1: Image: French police spot migrants moving around at night as they attempt to hop on the back of lorries
Those running after the lorries are powered by hope
column2: ambition and desperation. But for many of the police
column3: it is weary work. Rarely do they speak to journalists but on this occasion
column4: we strike up conversations with a group of officers from a unit of the CRS
column5: the French force that specialises in controlling crowds and dealing with public disorder.

column1: It is like this every day
column2: says Henri (that's not his real name)
column3: who's been coming to Calais for many years. ""Every day
column4: every day. I've seen everything. In fact

column1: We are standing by the roadside
column2: next to a hole in a security fence. He gently grabs my shoulder and points at a silhouette of a man in the distance. ""Look there. There he is. He's waiting for us to go. And as soon as we do
column3: then he'll be back here.

column1: There is no reason for any of these people to be here except to try to get on to a lorry. It's the only thing they want to do.""
Image: One French officer said he doesn't believe the attempted crossings will ever stop
I ask if it's changing at all and he nods. ""Yes
column2: for four or five months
column3: it's been getting worse.""

column1: What complicates his job is that none of these people even want to be in his country. ""They want to go to Britain
column2: to become legal and then I think lots of these people want to go to America
column3: he tells me. ""I talk to them. I even say 'what's wrong with France?' They say they think they are not welcome here. They all want to go to Britain - to England - and America.""

column1: Migrant crossings: 2021 marks record year with more 28
column2: 000 people entering UK via English Channel

column1: We spend some time with Henri and his team. They visit a lorry park
column2: and find that a fence has been pulled down
column3: even though it is topped with ferocious razor wire. The unit hunts for any people who might have got in
column4: but can't see anyone. Either they've fled
column5: or they're concealed inside a vehicle.

column1: Further down the road
column2: another apparently sturdy fence has been ripped open. Henri reckons it would cost two or three thousand euros to repair ""and it will be open again within a few days"".

column1: Image: Migrants try and make it to the UK without the help of people smugglers by accessing lorries
They fire tear gas to disperse a group of men who are gathering alongside a road
column2: waiting to jump on a vehicle. Later that evening
column3: another group throws branches on to a motorway to try to slow lorries enough to give them the chance to leap aboard. Three police vans rush to the scene; the cat reacting to the mice.

column1: It's not always about athletic endeavour
column2: of course. Plenty of lorries have suffered smashed locks or torn sides
column3: the signs of an unwanted visitor in a trailer. Drivers check their vehicles thoroughly
column4: knowing they face a fine of up to £2
column5: 000 for every person they may inadvertently bring into Britain.

column1: And even if a person does manage to avoid detection by the driver
column2: a stowaway might well be caught by security checks at the port. Frankly
column3: you have to be very lucky to get away with it

column1: That's what inspires the ones left behind; the ones queuing up at the roundabout to take a run at the next passing lorry. ""I don't think it will ever stop
column2: says Henri
column3: as he prepares to go off shift. He'll be back tomorrow night
column4: ready to face the same people

column22: 'restrictions'];"There is no winter sport resort quite like Chamonix. Nestled in the shadow of Mont Blanc
column23: it has a glittering history and a reputation for challenging even the best skiers.

column1: People travel from all around the world to try their luck on these slopes. And now
column2: the British can join them once again.

column1: For nearly a month
column2: holidaymakers were banned from crossing the Channel as a result of COVID restrictions. They were brought in when the Omicron variant was dominant in the UK
column3: but not much seen in France.

column1: Image: The only country that sends more tourists to the French Alps than Britain is France itself
Now
column2: that has changed; Omicron is omnipresent in both countries and
column3: after hesitating for a short while
column4: the French have reopened their border to British tourists. Many of those now crossing are heading towards the Alps.

column1: The only country that sends more tourists to the French Alps than Britain is France itself. In Chamonix
column2: it's reckoned that around one in four people on the slopes is British; in other resorts
column3: the ratio is even higher.

column1: Advertisement
What that means is that there are plenty of businesses in these mountains who depend on the Brits. And when they stopped coming
column2: those businesses started to worry.

column1: Image: Ski school founder Shona Tate says her Chamonix business depends on UK tourists being allowed to return
Shona Tate was among the nervous. She helped to found a ski school in Chamonix 18 years ago
column2: but says that the past two years have been the hardest time they've faced. She told me that her business depended on British tourists being allowed to return.

column1: If the restrictions hadn't been lifted then we wouldn't have been able to survive
column2: she said. ""You need cash flow to keep going. At the moment
column3: we're not even paying ourselves.

column1: The whole industry has taken a hit
column2: and it hasn't been pleasant. But as soon as the announcement came out that people could return
column3: well we got some lovely messages from clients. They were delighted for us
column4: and they wanted to know if they could come.

column1: I'm looking forward to Easter - I think it will be so much easier. Who knows what's ahead but we will keep positive at the moment.""
Not everything has been answered. Visitors still need to take a COVID test before arriving
column2: and unvaccinated tourists are not welcomed. The question of whether children need to have a vaccine passport has still not been resolved - but it looks very likely that they won't.

column1: Above us
column2: the sky is blue and cloudless. It is the perfect day to be on the slopes; you couldn't wish for a better advert.

column1: Image: The whole ski industry took a hit due to the pandemic but there is now a shared feeling of optimism
Giles Bickford leans on the balcony of his chalet and points up to Mont Blanc
column2: looming beyond us. The chalet is rented out to groups of tourists
column3: mostly British
column4: for fully-catered holidays. It's booked up for most of the rest of the year
column5: but those bookings were all likely to be cancelled if tourists were barred from entering France.

column3: without British tourists
column4: it would have been hard to pay the bills this year.

column1: As it's happened
column2: by getting this change in the middle of January
column3: we can survive. Any later and it would have been touch and go.""

column1: There is a shared feeling here - that disaster has been averted
column2: and that the opportunity now exists to move away from the economic impact of the pandemic and its ongoing travel restrictions. That having survived the storm
column3: it is time to reap the benefits.

column1: Up on the mountain

column3: creating that curious blend of refreshing cold and pleasant warmth that you sometimes get on a ski slope. The runs are not packed

column23: 'film'];"The owner of the UK's oldest cinema says the pandemic has created ""the biggest existential crisis"" ever faced by the industry.

column1: The Electric in Birmingham dates back to 1909 but enforced closure at the start of the pandemic led to it remaining shut for almost 22 months before finally reopening to the public this week.
It was taken over last year by Kevin Markwick
column2: who also owns The Uckfield Picture House in East Sussex. He's worked in the industry for his whole life and has never feared for the future of cinema like he has over the past two years.

column1: Image: The iconic Electric originally opened in 1909
This has been the biggest existential crisis we've ever faced
column2: he says.

column1: Not only were we obviously financially strapped all the way through because no money was coming in
column2: but you've still got to pay all the outgoings the film distributors rather went with indecent haste to home entertainment
column3: streaming and things like that so it wasn't entirely clear that we would have a steady supply of films when we came back.""

column1: Advertisement
When Universal's Trolls World Tour went straight to streaming in April 2020 it was the first major studio film to skip its planned cinema release.
With cinemas closed
column2: the industry was crippled. Before the pandemic in 2019 UK box office revenue exceeded £1.25bn. In 2020 it plummeted to just under £300m.

column1: Delays to the release dates of big blockbusters added to the industry's woes.
When the latest Bond film
column2: No Time to Die
column3: was eventually released last year it was the first sign of a revival. Spider-Man: No Way Home has also proved popular at the box office.

column1: In 2021 UK box office revenue rose slightly to over £556m
column2: an encouraging sign in a year when cinemas were closed for several months of lockdown
column3: but still well short of pre-pandemic revenue.

column1: Image: Roger Shannon
column2: a visiting professor of British Cinema Histories at Birmingham City University
column3: says 'the appetite for cinema hasn't gone away'

column1: Roger Shannon
column2: a visiting professor of British Cinema Histories at Birmingham City University
column3: believes the industry can be optimistic about the future
column4: despite changes in the way people enjoy films.

column1: I think the pandemic has accelerated that technological change and streamers have become more prominent
column2: he says.

column1: Of course we're all watching movies from our sofas… but I don't think it's an either-or situation.
Streamers are really revitalising
column2: recalibrating and reinvesting into the studio infrastructure in the UK
column3: which I think augers well for the long-term.

column1: I think cinema numbers will recover because I think that the appetite for cinema hasn't gone away and I think cinema will rebound with incredibly new ways of telling stories and I think the technological revolution means the stories will be told in different ways.""
Mr Markwick shares that optimism.
It's a completely different experience
column2: he says. ""It doesn't matter how big your TV is - you still need to get out of the house from time to time.""

column1: Image: Katie Marwick
column2: the manager of The Electric
column3: says interest in the reopening of the cinema has exceeded her expectations

column1: His daughter Katie
column2: who is the cinema's manager
column3: doesn't think streaming poses the threat others view it as.

column1: It's probably not even a case of competing I don't think to be honest because I think we can both exist in the same world
column2: she says.

column1: Watching a film in a cinema is completely different to watching it at home by yourself or with your family because watching a film in a cinema is such a communal experience. It all just builds and creates this amazing atmosphere.""
But she accepts that in order to thrive in 2022
column2: they're in the hands of the filmmakers.

column1: We need the films that were supposed to come out in 2020 to actually finally come out
column2: she says.

column1: Big blockbusters which will really coax people back into the cinema and big blockbusters that are only being shown in cinemas to begin with.""

Taking over such an iconic cinema brings with it the responsibility of continuing over a century of success. But so far the signs are good. Interest in the reopening of the cinema has exceeded her expectations.
Everyone's really excited with the phone ringing off the hook with everyone saying 'when are you open? When can I come back?' I think people are looking forward to it
