column20: 'developed'];"Scientists have developed video games using AI technology to diagnose

column1: The platform
column2: called Thymia
column3: aims to make depression and other mental health conditions as measurable as physical ailments.

column1: Dr Emilia Molimpakis
column2: CEO and co-founder of Thymia
column3: told Sky News: ""Right now the existing system is flawed in many ways
column5: the existing systems they have are subjective questionnaires that are incredibly biased and there's no follow-up between appointments.

column1: Image: Software analyses the patient's voice
column2: eye gaze and micro-expressions along behavioural measures

column1: Thymia is the first system that offers objectivity and uses several types of data in order to create a really accurate and robust model of depression.""
The programme asks patients to play simple video games
column2: with a neuropsychological underpinning
column3: ultimately designed to measure depressive cues.

column1: Advertisement
While playing the games
column2: the software analyses the patient's voice
column3: eye gaze and micro-expressions as well as behavioural measures including reaction times

column1: Through this
column2: patterns indicative of depression are picked up on
column3: allowing a diagnosis to be made quickly.

column1: As it is designed to monitor patients in the long-term
column2: patients can play games in-between appointments
column3: helping identify whether treatments are working over time.

column1: Image: Dr Emilia Molimpakis is hopeful the Thymia programme will help clinicians achieve a diagnosis for depression much faster
Dr Molimpakis said: ""What we hope to achieve is to help clinicians achieve the right diagnosis much faster - currently it takes years
column2: we want to reduce that to weeks - and also help them find the right treatment for each individual patient.""

column1: Posy Parsons first began to experience symptoms of depression in her mid-20s.
Currently
column2: diagnostic tools used to diagnose depression involve patients scoring their feelings - something Ms Parsons struggled with.

column1: Already facing challenges at the time
column2: getting a diagnosis came with its own challenges.

column1: She told Sky News: ""All the doctor receives is that one form and they've got no context of what else is going on and all the different complexities of the situation.
You really feel like it is this quick snapshot and then they're judging and making potential huge consequences for your life based on that.""
She says being able to see the objective measurements of depression would ""help recognise that it's a real thing"" - and would help her keep track of her own mental wellbeing.
Thymia has been trialled by around 2
column2: 000 patients at University College London and King's College London
column3: with clinical trials beginning later this year.

column1: Image: Posy Parsons says seeing objective measurements of depression would be helpful
But there is concern over whether the technology will have the desired effect
column2: with some saying the root of the problem needs to be the primary focus.

column1: Ratchet And Clank: Rift Apart - the latest sci-fi video game shining a spotlight on mental health
Dr Lucy Johnstone
column2: a consultant clinical psychologist
column3: told Sky News: ""It's a fair point to say we're not very good at picking up
column4: or understanding or supporting people who are feeling depressed.

column1: I'm just not sure this is the answer.
A quick check list is not going to tell you a great deal but nor is sitting down through a video game of some sort that looks at your eye gaze.
I actually think as a psychologist what we need to find out more is the reasons people are feeling the way they are.
We actually know a lot about the life circumstances that lead people to become depressed.
We actually need a human being sitting down and asking you more about those events in your lives
column2: that's actually what's going to help us understand people better.""";https://web.archive.org/web/20220123040917/https://news.sky.com/story/video-games-that-diagnose-monitor-and-treat-depression-developed-by-scientists-12521681;

column23: 'ministers'];"Nusrat Ghani made history in 2018.

column1: Colleagues cheered as the Kashmir-born MP got to her feet.

column1: Advertisement
Ms Ghani now says she was told at the time that her ""Muslimness"" had made colleagues feel uncomfortable.
The East Sussex MP did raise these complaints at the time and is said to have been ""invited"" to make a formal complaint.
However
column2: in an interview with the Sunday Times she says she was told she would have been ""ostracised"" by colleagues and had her ""career destroyed"" if she had pursued the issue.

column1: Image: Nusrat Ghani says she was told that her 'Muslimness' made colleagues feel uncomfortable
The former minister has also expressed concern about the robustness of the internal Conservative Party complaints process.
This is a potentially damaging development for a government fighting accusations of a toxic internal culture and a prime minister who has previously been criticised for his comments about Islam.

An independent investigation into accusations of islamophobia in the Conservative Party - promised by leadership candidates in 2019 and published last year - was widely criticised as a whitewash with its terms of reference set too tight.

But the reaction from senior Tory MPs and cabinet ministers is also instructive about the broader health of the government.
Late on Saturday night

column1: Image: Chief Whip Mark Spencer says Ms Ghani's allegations relate to him

column2: the Chief Whip Mark Spencer
column3: and a difference in tone

column1: Senior ministers have been notably more muscular in recent weeks
This could be put down to the seriousness of the accusations
column2: if it wasn't for other instances of Boris Johnson's top team beginning to push in different directions.

column1: On COVID restrictions and tax rises
column2: senior ministers have been notably more muscular in recent weeks.

column1: Further down the party
column2: arguments that - in times of stability - would be shut down by government are beginning to break out into the open.

column1: Frame that in the context of the recent barrage of scandals rolling into No 10
column2: and it's hard not to see a correlation between the waning authority of the prime minister and the increased instability within his administration and party.

column1: Prosecutors will try to prove that all three defendants willingly denied Mr Floyd his constitutional rights - by depriving him of his liberty without due process of law.

column1: While harsh sentences are rarely brought in these federal civil rights cases

column1: Image: George Floyd responds to police after they approached his car in Minneapolis. Pic: AP

column5: it could go all the way up to life. A lot will ultimately depend on which officer is found guilty of what counts
column6: as well as the need to balance their sentences against that of Mr Chauvin.""

column1: How unusual are these charges?

column17: 'died'];"A man who took his dead uncle into an Irish post office to claim his pension insists he did not realise he had passed away.

column1: Declan Haughney told the Irish Mirror he and another man took Peadar Doyle
column3: on a five-minute walk from his home on Pollerton Road
column5: to collect his pension last Friday morning.

column1: The 40-year-old said he had lived with his uncle throughout his life and believes he may have died on the way to Hosey's post office on Staplestown Road.
He said he and another man linked arms with him and dragged him to the post office.
He was walking like normal and then I reckon he died
column2: he said
column3: adding that Mr Doyle started ""dragging his heels"" at one point.

column1: Advertisement
We were grand like then all of a sudden he started going all slumpy
column2: he said.

column1: We thought nothing of it because Peadar had had heart attacks and all.""
He said they let him go at the post office counter and it was only after he dropped to the floor that they realised he had died.
Mr Haughney said he believes he is being falsely accused of trying to claim his uncle's pension because he previously stole from his aunt and served two years in prison.
He said: ""Why would I want to rob my uncle?
I'm 40 years of age yeah
column2: I'm not a child
column3: I'm not a young fella.

column1: I'm not an eejit to walk into Hoseys with a dead man and collect his money.
Am I cuckoo? Am I cuckoo? I'm not.""
Irish police also believe Mr Doyle died before his body reached the post office at 11am
column2: according to the Irish Times.

column1: Foul play has reportedly been ruled out but a post-mortem was only able to estimate the time of death as some time on Friday morning.
Police have not yet determined whether the retired painter was already dead when taken from the house.

When the group approached
column2: a ""concerned staff member enquired about the wellbeing of the man""
column3: the Irish Times said.

column1: At that point
column2: the two others ""dropped the man and left the post office""
column3: the paper added.

column1: Staff then apparently attended to the man and found he had died.
According to RTE
column2: a man initially called into the post office to collect a pension on behalf of an elderly man.

column1: He was apparently told
column2: however
column3: that the recipient had to be present
column4: and two men arrived a short time later with the deceased.

column1: No money was handed over

column1: Mr Haughney has not been arrested.

column20: 'variant'];"The World Health Organisation has criticised political leaders for comparing coronavirus to flu again and stressed it is still ""full of very nasty surprises"" despite restrictions lifting in the UK.

column1: Announcing the scrapping of Plan B measures in England last week
column2: Health Secretary Sajid Javid said that with ""Omicron in retreat"" we ""must learn to live with COVID"" as it could be ""with us forever"".

column1: But Dr David Nabarro
column2: WHO special envoy on COVID-19
column3: warned that ""governments everywhere should not suggest the data has suddenly changed
column4: or the virus got incredibly weak"".

column1: Follow live coronavirus updates from the UK and around the world
He suggested that although the end of the pandemic ""is in sight""
column2: Europe is only ""passing the halfway mark in a marathon"" with a ""long
column3: long way to trudge"".

column1: Advertisement
Here Sky News speaks to scientists about what challenges lie between the UK removing COVID measures and the global pandemic being declared officially over.
Please use Chrome browser for a more accessible video player 3:10 WHO: Don't compare COVID to flu
Approaching end of Omicron - but not COVID
At the start of January
column2: the number of Omicron cases in the UK peaked at nearly 200
column3: 000 a day but have been falling considerably since then.

column1: Although such high levels of infection in December and good uptake of booster jabs mean most of the population have a higher level of immunity against Omicron
column2: new variants are still likely to emerge.

column1: Professor Andrew Preston
column2: of the University of Bath's biology and biochemistry department
column3: told Sky News that seemingly the main factor driving the government's decisions on COVID is the ""long-term trajectory of the variant we have at the moment"".

column1: But he warns: ""We have seen that COVID can significantly change its behaviour - first with the Alpha variant
column2: then Delta and now with Omicron.

column1: We're approaching a point in the UK where Omicron is in a steady state.
But there's nothing to say that there won't be another variant in the future that will be more virulent.""
Professor Lawrence Young
column2: an expert in molecular oncology at the University of Warwick
column3: also stressed the ""big ongoing threat of new variants"".

column1: He said: ""The longer the virus is allowed to spread in populations that aren't completely vaccinated
column2: the more likely it is to mutate.

column1: We avoid that endless cycle of new variants by helping the global effort on vaccination
column2: but also maintaining surveillance (testing) capacity.""

column1: No guarantee next variant will be milder
With some other viruses there is evidence that in order to survive
column2: new variants must become less severe.

column1: Professor Preston explains that viruses like COVID which only live in humans are ""dependent on having live humans around"".
Therefore
column2: if the virus is so severe that it ""kills its hosts at high frequency… the number of available hosts will start to dwindle and if this continues it will die out"".

column1: Please use Chrome browser for a more accessible video player 0:47 Omicron 'hard to outcompete' for future variants
He explains: ""In this case
column2: a variant that is able to transmit to a new host without killing it will be fitter - as it will maintain the supply of hosts and therefore its niche on the planet.""

column1: This means that future COVID variants may continue to be milder
column2: like Omicron.

column1: But he warns: ""This isn't necessarily a given
column2: and the opposite can be true.""

column1: Professor Young gives the examples of measles
column2: malaria and Ebola
column3: none of which have become ""any easier to deal with"" over time.

column1: They are no less aggressive or pathogenic than they were - they're still very dangerous diseases.""
Waning vaccine immunity
The latest UK Health Security Agency (UKHSA) data suggests that vaccine effectiveness against hospitalisation from Omicron reduces to only 52% after six months with only two doses.
But with a third jab that increases again to 88%.
However
column2: with the NHS still under huge pressures from Omicron staff absences and backlogs from two years of COVID delays
column3: it is unlikely to be able vaccinate people at such a frequent rate.

column1: Waning immunity of our current vaccine is another concerning thing
column2: Professor Young says.

column1: Follow the Daily podcast on Apple Podcasts
column2: Google Podcasts
column3: Spotify

column1: The whole population can't be vaccinated every six months or a year.""
He adds that reduced vaccine efficacy is particularly an issue in schools
column2: where millions of five to 11-year-olds are unvaccinated and able to spread the virus easily.

column1: We could end up in an endless cycle of children infecting adults with waning immunity
column2: he says.

column1: The hope is that with current vaccines and the high levels of Omicron we've seen people are double-protected.""
Scientists are also working on improved vaccines with built-in protection against new variants
column2: he adds.

column1: Removing testing and self-isolation will leave us 'blind'
In response to reports lateral flow tests will soon no longer be free and widely available
column2: the government has said they will be for ""as long as necessary"".

column1: Prime Minister Boris Johnson has said that he wants to remove the legal requirement to self-isolate if you have COVID by 24 March - if not earlier.
Please use Chrome browser for a more accessible video player 3:15 Is govt ready to end isolation against WHO guidance?
Professor Preston suggests that delaying this until the Easter school holidays - or when the weather has improved so there is less indoor mixing - would be better.
And on testing
column2: Professor Young warns: ""Removing testing will mean you don't know where the virus is and how it's spreading.

column1: Then you are completely blind to outbreaks
column2: and particularly with those who are higher-risk
column3: not having targeted testing is very worrying.""

column1: Modellers at the University of Warwick have also predicted an 'exit wave' of between 1
column2: 000 and 2
column3: 000 Omicron cases a day at some point this summer once restrictions lift.

column1: Professor Young adds: ""It's going to be very likely that we see a rebound of Omicron.
It's very
column2: very infectious
column3: so it's hard to see how we wouldn't get huge levels of infection again.""

column1: The emergence of the BA.2 sub-lineage of Omicron as a 'variant under investigation' also ""reiterates the importance of testing to monitor the arrival of new variants""
column2: he adds.

column1: Clinically vulnerable paying price for return to normalcy
Over the course of the pandemic
column2: some scientists and politicians have caused controversy by putting their weight behind the concept of so-called 'herd immunity'.

column1: This is when so much of the population has developed immunity to the virus by being infected that there are not enough left for it to keep reproducing - causing it to eventually peter out.

But although the UK has seen such high levels of Omicron cases over the past two months - recent ONS data suggests Omicron is 16 times more likely to reinfect people who have already had it than Delta was.
This means
column2: Professor Preston says
column3: that the ""traditional concept of herd immunity doesn't apply"" with Omicron.

column1: He also stresses that herd immunity strategies do not protect the clinically vulnerable - as they cannot risk becoming infected.
Please use Chrome browser for a more accessible video player 4:56 COVID fears for the immunocompromised
We need to be empathetic and recognise that while for most of us
column2: there's no more we can do to avoid COVID
column3: for some people the anxiety and risk of getting it is much

column1: It will be them paying the price for our return to normalcy.""
He adds that the NHS may be able to facilitate annual boosters for the immunocompromised ""for a few years"" - but they would not offer ""100% protection"".
We don't know how long that protection would last for the super-vulnerable
column2: he says.

column1: Globally end of pandemic could take 'a few years'
WHO has repeatedly said that the pandemic will continue as long as the significant parts of the planet are unvaccinated.

Professor Young adds that we need to ""learn from past experiences"" and that despite the government promising last July would be the removal of the last set of restrictions - they had to be reimposed just months later.
Where we have a raging pandemic elsewhere
column2: we can never say we're completely out of it - we're not a moated castle
column3: he says.

column1: Professor Preston says that ""over the next few years"" different countries will experience COVID at differing levels.
If Omicron does spread worldwide
column2: then we will reach a point where everyone has had it and there are a steady number of cases through reinfections
column3: he says.

column2: a separate group of chimpanzees living less than four miles away did use the tools to crack nuts.

column1: Dr Koops said this suggested the primates ""acquire cultural behaviours more like humans and do not simply invent a complex tool use behaviour like nut cracking on their own"".

column21: 'stronger'];"The Islamic State attack on Gweiran Prison was brazen but inevitable.

column1: The tempo of IS activity has been slowly building over recent months and the group has always made clear its intentions to storm the many prisons that now dot north-east Syrian countryside.
The prisons have long been a ticking time-bomb and the Kurds have been warning the West for years that they were struggling to cope.
The US and UK have donated millions of pounds in training
column2: equipment and security features
column3: but it isn't enough.

column1: Image: A car bomb was used to breach the prison's perimeter. Pic: Anha Hawar News
Many of the prisons are makeshift and not designed to hold inmates for years on end.
Advertisement
The prisoners are kept in dreadful conditions
column2: in cramped cells
column3: breeding an environment rife for uprising.

column1: Let's not forget that it was in coalition-controlled prisons in Iraq post-2003 that many of IS's senior leaders met
column2: planned and prepared for the creation of the group.

column1: The Syrian Democratic Forces simply don't have the money or capability of holding tens of thousands Islamic State prisoners indefinitely
column2: many of them foreign fighters who could be dispersed back to stand trial in their home countries.

column1: But as much as this might have been inevitable
column2: an attack of this scale suggests a serious failure of SDF intelligence; US too.

column1: American forces are on the ground in the area and regularly carry out patrols
column2: coalition aircraft fly daily intelligence and surveillance missions.

column1: How did the planning for an assault of this kind go unmissed?
We can't dismiss the possibility that someone or some people were paid off - how else do you park two cars laden with explosives right outside the walls of the largest IS prison in Syria?
Intelligence failings aside
column2: this shows Islamic State is still capable of carrying out an attack of this complexity and size.

column1: Image: Islamic State fighters who were arrested after the prison was attacked. Pic: SDF via AP
Syria's competing factions had led to an absence of co-ordination which IS has exposed
column2: moving fighters and equipment around the country
column3: often untracked.

column1: The Global Coalition has described the prison break as ""a desperate attempt for it to replenish its ranks and regain lost momentum"".
I don't fully agree.

column2: the United Nations estimated there were still around 10
column3: 000 IS fighters in Iraq and Syria - no small number.

column1: The Gweiran Prison holds between 3
column3: 000 IS fighters - it's no surprise that IS would at some point have a crack at breaking them out.

column1: And they've succeeded - we don't know how many have escaped
column2: and probably never will
column3: but the Islamic State group is slightly bigger and more emboldened than it was this time last week.

column1: And as for momentum
column2: the assault on Gweiran Prison is by some way the group's biggest success in three years or more
column3: but it comes after months of smaller attacks in Syria and elsewhere around the world.

column1: Unquestionably
column2: IS will use the prison break for propaganda purposes.

column1: It will be a considerable boost to sleeper cells in Iraq and Syria
column2: as well as affiliates in Afghanistan and parts of Africa.

column1: Islamic State is nothing like the force it was five years ago
column2: but neither has it disappeared - it is showing signs of growing slowly stronger.

column1: This won't be the last attack of this kind.";https://web.archive.org/web/20220125041911/http://news.sky.com/story/syria-islamic-state-slowly-showing-signs-of-growing-stronger-after-prison-raid-12524522;

column19: 'reach'];"The world's most powerful space telescope has reached its final stop - one million miles from Earth - a month after setting off on its historic voyage.

column1: The James Webb Telescope fired rocket thrusters for about five minutes in a final course correction to enter orbit around the sun
column2: with NASA confirming it had gone to plan.

column1: Flight controllers back in Baltimore celebrated and NASA administrator Bill Nelson said it meant ""we're one step closer to uncovering the mysteries of the universe"".
🏠 Home
column2: home on Lagrange! We successfully completed our burn to start #NASAWebb on its orbit of the 2nd Lagrange point (L2)
column3: about a million miles (1.5 million km) from Earth. It will orbit the Sun
column5: as it orbits L2. https://t.co/bsIU3vccAj #UnfoldTheUniverse pic.twitter.com/WDhuANEP5h — NASA Webb Telescope (@NASAWebb) January 24

column1: James Webb will give a view further back in time than ever before
column2: to the formation of the first galaxies and stars 13.7 billion years ago.

column1: It will also scan for signs of alien life.
Advertisement
Considerably bigger than its predecessor
column2: the Hubble telescope
column3: the new observatory has a 6.5-metre gold-coated mirror and a sunshield as big as a tennis court.

column1: The £7.5bn telescope - named after a former NASA chief - launched on Christmas Day from French Guiana and had been decades in the making.
More on James Webb Space Telescope NASA's new James Webb Telescope completes the final stage of deployment after being fully unfolded in space
The mirror
column2: which was folded into the rocket's nose for blast off
column3: was unfurled successfully a few weeks ago.

column1: Image: The huge mirror will hopefully help unlock previously unknown secrets of the Universe. Pic: NASA/Chris Gunn
Monday's final stop saw the telescope inserted at the second Lagrange point - or L2
column2: where the gravitational forces of the sun and Earth balance.

column1: The final mid-course burn added only about 3.6 miles per hour (1.6 metres per second) - a mere walking pace - to Webb's speed
column2: which was all that was needed to send it to its preferred 'halo' orbit around the L2 point
column3: said NASA.

column1: Scientists for the space agency say the pull of the sun and Earth will keep the telescope in place and mean little additional rocket thrust is needed.
It will always face Earth's night side to keep its infrared detectors as cold as possible.
Image: The telescope was launched on Christmas Day
Observations from the telescope will not start until June.
The mirror is made of 18 segments which must now be carefully aligned to achieve its proper focus.
Ground teams will also spend several months activating and calibrating instruments
column2: such as the camera and spectrograph.

column1: The James Webb project is led by NASA in partnership with the European and Canadian space agencies.";https://web.archive.org/web/20220125050856/http://news.sky.com/story/james-webb-telescope-fires-thrusters-to-reach-final-stop-a-million-miles-from-earth-and-begins-orbit-around-sun-12524664;

column17: 'protect'];"Lucky fat genes can help protect obese people from certain diseases

column1: Fat stored under the skin
column2: like a paunch or a double chin
column3: is considered less harmful than fat stored around organs such as the liver and heart.

column1: And according to researchers
column2: the genes people are born with determine how and where this fat is stored.

column1: Those with the lucky genes tend to have their fat stored under the skin rather than on their organs - reducing the risk of some diseases.
Read more: Pharmacies to offer NHS weight-loss scheme without referral from GP
Advertisement
Anyone with a body mass index (BMI) over 30 is considered obese.
But two people with the same BMI can have very different amounts of fat
column2: and that fat can be distributed in different places throughout the body.

column1: Scientists say the study's findings could explain why some obese people remain relatively healthy
column2: while others suffer from life-changing conditions such as heart disease.

column1: Lead researcher from Brunel University London
column2: Dr Hanieh Yaghootkar said: ""Some people have unlucky fat genes
column3: meaning they store higher levels of fat everywhere

column1: That's associated with a higher risk of diseases such as type 2 diabetes.
Read more: COVID-19 pandemic shines 'harsh light' on rising obesity in young people as NHS launches 15 clinics to tackle issue
Others are luckier and have genes that mean higher fat under the skin but lower liver fat and a lower risk of diseases like type 2 diabetes.""
As part of the study
column2: 37 diseases were tested. A total of 12 of those
column3: including coronary artery disease and stroke
column4: were found to be directly related to the genes which determine where the fat is stored.

column1: Nine of the conditions were found to be unrelated to where a person's fat is stored and instead were most likely a result of simply carrying too much weight. These included deep vein thrombosis and arthritic knees.
People still urged to consider obesity as a hazard to their health
However
column2: researchers continue to warn people that being obese is still a serious health hazard - regardless of fat storage location.

column1: It is hoped the study will help doctors to determine if they should be targeting the adverse effects of someone's obesity
column2: or be trying to get them to shed a few pounds.

column1: Professor of human genetics at the University of Exeter
column2: Timothy Frayling said: ""For example
column3: there are many treatments that can lower the high-fat levels in the blood and around the organs that do not affect the extra weight a person carries.

column1: In contrast
column2: for other conditions
column3: it may be more important to reduce the extra weight as much as
column5: the damaging high sugar and fat levels in the blood.""

column1: The study
column2: published in the journal eLife collected information from 500
column3: 000 individuals aged 37 to 73 between 2006 and 2010 from across the UK.";https://web.archive.org/web/20220125070804/http://news.sky.com/story/obesity-lucky-fat-genes-can-help-protect-overweight-people-from-certain-diseases-study-suggests-12524699;

column22: 'irish'];"The grieving father of three children killed by his wife has said their loss hits him every day ""like a sledgehammer"".

column1: Speaking to Sky News on the second anniversary of the tragedy
column2: Andrew McGinley said he is now calling for legal reform in the Republic of Ireland to ensure the families of those who are mentally ill can be included in their treatment.

column1: On 24 January 2020
column2: Andrew's children Conor
column3: nine
column6: and three-year-old Carla were suffocated at the family home in Newcastle
column7: Co Dublin by their mother Deirdre Morley.

column1: Image: Mr McGinley is calling for legal reform to ensure the families of those who are mentally ill can be included in their treatment
In May 2021 she was found not guilty of their murders by reason of insanity and was committed to the Central Mental Hospital in Dublin.
Two years ago
column2: Mr McGinley returned to his home from work as the emergency services arrived.

column1: Advertisement
I just arrived back and the first responders were there
column2: the medics and the fire brigade
column3: he said.

column1: It was then I thought 'where are the children?' I discovered the bodies in the house when I went in. You just think 'how does this happen to you
column2: how does it happen to your family?'

column1: You read about it elsewhere. You just look for answers and two years later I'm still looking for answers. I know exactly how the children died. Now I just need to know why.""
Deirdre Morley had been receiving psychiatric care before the deaths
column2: but Andrew said he hadn't realised the full extent of her illness.

column1: Image: Deirdre Morley (right) was found not guilty of the children's murders by reason of insanity and committed to the Central Mental Hospital in Dublin
Shortly before the children were killed
column2: he said: ""Deirdre was talking about going back to work and was talking about recovery
column3: about being nearly fully recovered.""

column1: 'It left me with more questions'
Now the bereaved father wants legislative reform so that families of those who are mentally ill can be included in their treatment.
Image: Mr McGinley has honoured his eldest son
column2: Conor
column3: with a YouTube channel

column1: With every piece of information that came out in the trial
column2: there was so much I was hearing for the first time
column3: he said. ""It's just left me with so many more questions.

column1: If I was included all the way along
column2: I wouldn't have those questions
column3: I'd already know the answers. I just think it's vital for the support circle of people getting treatment

column1: Asked if he has forgiven his wife

column3: it was relayed through the Garda files what Conor's last words were
column4: and they haunt me. It's difficult.

column1: Image: Mrs Morley had been receiving psychiatric care before the deaths
I understand she was ill. The Dee I knew and loved was a loving
column2: caring mother
column3: she was a nurse. I accept she was ill

column1: 'You never recover
column2: you cope'

column1: Mr McGinley has now honoured his eldest child Conor's wishes for a YouTube channel by creating Conor's Clips
column2: where he uploads videos of his children to nearly 8
column3: 000 subscribers.

column1: It was something he [Conor] had asked me about before Christmas 2020

column1: It's helped me cope. Helped me manage somewhat. People talk about recovery. You never recover
column2: you cope and you manage.

column3: what's happened.

column1: But then the next thing I think about is what I can do for the kids
column2: and what can I do with Conor's Clips. That's what helps me.""

column1: Image: Mr McGinley says waking up every day is ""like a sledgehammer""
Mr McGinley has also set up a charity for his second son
column2: called As Darragh Did
column3: which marked the second anniversary by allocating €16
column5: and a snowman-themed colouring competition called Snowman for Carla.

column1: He says these legacy projects are a way of keeping his children's memories alive

Disclosures surrounding a range of gatherings in Downing Street and a number of government departments during COVID restrictions in 2020 and 2021 have put pressure on Boris Johnson

column2: which was described by one of his aides as a ""bring your own booze"" event.

column1: But he has claimed he thought it was a ""work event"" and that ""nobody told me"" it was against the rules.

column1: And she said the fact that police were now investigating a number of events does not mean that fixed penalty notices ""will necessarily be issued in every instance and to every person involved"".

column2: but they were not thought to have reached the threshold for criminal investigation
column3: the commissioner told the London Assembly.

column1: Met chief explains police approach to past allegations of rule-breaking

column2: Commissioner Dick said it would ""not normally be"" a proportionate use of the Met's resources.

column1: But she said investigations were launched for ""the most serious and flagrant type of breach"" where there was evidence and three criteria were met.

column2: or ought to have known that what they were doing was an offence.

column1: Where not investigating would significantly undermine the legitimacy of the law.
And where there was little ambiguity around the absence of any reasonable defence.
So in those cases
column2: where those criteria were met
column3: the guidelines suggested that we should potentially investigate further and end up giving people tickets.""

column1: 'We police without fear or favour'

column2: Commissioner Dick was told that public trust in the Met had ""severely waned"" given how the parties in Downing Street had taken place in such proximity to the force's officers.

column17: 'hobson'];"Children's and social care services at Bradford Council are to be placed in a trust in the wake of the Star Hobson case.

column1: The council had contact with the family of 16-month-old Star before she was murdered by her mother's girlfriend.
The not-for-profit trust will be owned by the council but operate at arms-length under the control of a new independent chair and board of directors.
The trust will ""drive rapid improvements"" after recommendations made to Education Secretary Nadhim Zahawi by the children's services commissioner in the West Yorkshire city.
Image: Education Secretary Nadhim Zahawi says 'keeping vulnerable children safe from harm is non-negotiable'
Mr Zahawi said: ""Keeping vulnerable children safe from harm is non-negotiable. Where a council is not meeting its duty to do this
column2: we will take action to protect children and put their needs first.

column1: Advertisement

It's clear from the recommendations made by the commissioner in Bradford that the council needs support to improve and so I'm pleased that Bradford Council have agreed to establish a new trust that will bring positive change for the council and independent oversight that drives improvements.
This is an important moment for children and families in Bradford
column2: and for social workers and other professionals who want to create meaningful and effective relationships with them.

column1: These professionals take highly complex decisions each day to protect children
column2: and I am grateful for the effort that goes into each one.""

column19: 'brockhill'];"Star Hobson was just 16 months old when she died of ""catastrophic injuries"" inflicted on her at her West Yorkshire home.

column1: Following a seven-week trial
column2: Star's mother Frankie Smith

column1: Brockhill was found guilty of Star's murder. Smith was found guilty of causing or allowing the death of a child.
Please use Chrome browser for a more accessible video player 0:23 Star Hobson murderer's 'psycho' video
The court heard concerned family and friends made at least five referrals to social services in the eight months leading up to her death.
However
column2: the case was repeatedly closed as the local authority failed to recognise the scale of abuse that was being inflicted on the toddler.

column1: Warning: This story contains distressing details about the treatment and subsequent death of a child.
Image: Star Hobson died in September 2020 from injuries she received at her home
Smith gave birth to Star just before her 18th birthday
column2: in May 2019.

column1: Months later
column2: she separated from Star's father
column3: Jordan Hobson
column4: and quickly began a relationship with Brockhill after they met at a pub.

column1: The first referral is made
Smith's friend Hollie Jones raised concerns over the care of Star and potential domestic violence issues between the couple and made the first referral on 23 January 2020.
Police and social services visited
column2: but no concerns were raised
column3: and the case was dropped.

column1: In February
column2: Smith's great-grandmother
column3: Anita Smith
column4: looked after Star for 10 weeks. She said when she picked Star up
column5: the child appeared depressed and had lost weight.

column1: Smith visited Star a couple of times when she was under Anita's care
column2: with Star gaining weight and seeming happier.

column1: Image: Frankie Smith (left) and Savannah Brockhill deny murder and causing or allowing the death of a child. Pic Facebook
Referrals dismissed
In May 2020
column2: Anita Smith made a second referral to social services - but the case was closed
column3: with the couple claiming the complaint was ""malicious"".

column1: The following month
column2: Jordan Hobson put the third referral in to social services after seeing a video of Star on Facebook where she had bruises on her face.

column1: Smith blamed this on an accident involving a coffee table
column2: and although she was taken to hospital by social services
column3: the doctor concluded it was nothing unusual.

column1: Two days later
column2: a close friend of Smith's mother made a fourth referral. Videos taken on Brockhill's phone around this time show a number of clips where Star appears exhausted and treated without love - including one where she falls off her chair and a laugh is heard.

column1: On 2 September
column2: a fifth referral is made by Frank Smith
column3: Star's paternal great-grandfather. Police and social services visited

column1: Smith dismisses concerns over bruising
An unannounced visit on 4 September saw Smith brush off concerns about bruising.
The house officer then attempted to arrange a meeting
column2: but Smith repeatedly postponed
column3: making excuses such as Star having a sickness bug.

column1: Nine days later
column2: CCTV images appeared to show Brockhill striking Star 21 times while she is staying with her at work. The footage
column3: from a camera at a recycling plant in Doncaster where Brockhill was working
column4: showed her delivering repeated blows to the child over the course of three hours while she sat in her car seat.

column1: On 15 September
column2: social services closed the case.

column1: Star died a week later
column2: on 22 September.

column1: The day before
column2: CCTV showed her mother dragging her through Bradford like a puppet
column3: with the toddler seen crying when she tried to walk.

column1: Image: Star's mother brushed off concerns about bruising
The day of Star's murder
On the day of Star's death
column2: Smith texted Brockhill that she had ""had enough"".

column1: In an exchange
column2: Brockhill said: ""You doing? x""

column1: Smith replied: ""Sorting this child out
column2: gave her food and she ate it all and now she's sat on the floor saying no and nipping and biting her arm.""

column1: Brockhill: ""Daft child.""
Smith: ""Ragged my hair out
column2: smacked me
column3: sick to death of it.""

column1: Brockhill: ""Do what you did last night and put her in a corner.""
Smith: ""Done it. Stood crying at the wall.""
Brockhill: ""Good x""
Just before 3pm
column2: Brockhill arrived at Smith's flat to discover Star had torn up a ticket from Smith's favourite band. The internet search history on Brockhill's phone showed ""Rubettes signed ticket"" at 3.03pm.

column1: At 3.34pm
column2: the internet search history on Smith's phone showed ""how to bring a baby out of shock"" and ""shock in babies"".

column1: At 3.45pm
column2: Smith called 112
column3: which went through to an operator in Glasgow. Glasgow then contacted West Yorkshire Police
column4: and at the same time Smith texted 999.

column1: Four minutes later
column2: Smith's phone was put through to the ambulance service
column3: where Brockhill tells the operator she ""heard a bang"" and found Star on the floor.

column1: Paramedics arrived at 4.04pm to find Star lifeless and pale
column2: wearing only a disposable nappy.

column1: She was taken to hospital and pronounced dead just before 5pm.
Image: A referral was dismissed as 'malicious'
Social services response
A joint statement from safeguarding agencies in Bradford said they ""deeply regret"" missing warning signs in Star's case.
The statement was given by Marium Haque
column2: interim director of children's services at Bradford Council
column3: Helen Hirst

column5: this remains a moment of maximum peril for Mr Johnson. There are now three main ways Mr Johnson’s premiership could potentially end. The first is a fatal blow in the Sue Gray report

column18: 'arrest'];"A man who suffocated a suspected burglar while performing a citizen's arrest in the street has been cleared of manslaughter.

column1: Nathan Smith
column2: a 38-year-old carer
column3: knelt on Craig Wiltshire's back for nine minutes in the early hours of 20 November 2019 after tackling him to the ground.

column1: He refused to ease off when the victim
column3: told him he could not breathe twice
column4: telling him ""I don't give a s*** what you can and can't do"".

column1: Mr Wiltshire died in hospital two weeks later.
On Wednesday
column2: a jury at Bristol Crown Court cleared Smith of manslaughter after four hours and seven minutes of deliberations.

column1: Advertisement
Smith said he believed Mr Wiltshire was ""pretending"" to be in distress so that he would be released and could escape
column2: and denied any wrongdoing.

column1: Mr Wiltshire was suspected of being behind a string of thefts and break-ins in the Bristol suburb where Smith was working as a live-in carer.
However
column2: there was no active police investigation into the crimes despite repeated complaints to the police
column3: so the thief was never caught.

column1: Image: A court artist sketch of Smith standing trial
Victim had pre-existing heart condition
A post-mortem revealed that Mr Wiltshire had the sedative diazepam and the heroin-substitute methadone in his system
column2: as well as a pre-existing heart condition.

column1: Smith said he was unaware that the victim was vulnerable to cardiorespiratory arrest
column2: and that he did not know leaving someone in the prone position for a prolonged period of time was dangerous.

column1: During the trial
column2: the prosecution argued that Smith took the opportunity to punish Mr Wiltshire for his alleged crimes because he was angry.

column1: Prosecutor James Ward said Smith hurled abusive insults at the victim including calling him a ""f****** piece of shit"" as proof he wanted to hurt him.

Smith said in response: ""I was being loud so other people would come
column2: I didn't want to shout 'help' so he knew I needed help
column3: and I wanted to make him think I was more in control than I was.""

column1: He denied being angry or wanting to punish Mr Wiltshire
column2: adding: ""I just wanted the police to come and get him.""

column1: Smith also told the court he feared Mr Wiltshire had a weapon on him because he had been reaching for his pockets.

Professor Jason Payne-James
column2: expert in forensic and legal medicine
column3: told the court he did not believe Smith's method of restraint
column4: as a member of the public with no training

column1: He added: ""In terms of the persistence of the prone restraint
column2: I believe that would have been inappropriate if police personnel had continued that for that length of time without moving or monitoring (Mr Wiltshire).""

column1: Jurors also heard from a neighbour in the area
column2: Kimberly Lock
column3: who said the community had been ""terrorised"" by the break-ins
column4: adding she had extra locks fitted to her house
column5: including a sliding bolt to her bedroom.

column1: CCTV footage also captured Smith's employer Michael Crooks adding his weight to Mr Wiltshire for a few minutes

column1: Both have admitted a charge of common assault and were not charged with manslaughter.

column19: 'risk'];"Bangladeshi people and Pakistani men living in the UK were most at risk of dying during the third wave of COVID

column1: Data released by the Office for National Statics found people from these two groups remained at higher risk of death from COVID-19 during the third wave - even after adjusting for vaccination status.
From 13 June 2021 onwards
column2: the risk for Bangladeshi communities from the virus was 4.4 and 5.2 times greater than white British men and women.

column1: COVID news latest - New variant could prolong current wave

column2: even taking vaccination status into account

column1: It was more than two times greater even when adjusting for vaccine status and other variables such as socio-economic factors.

column2: Pakistani men were found to be 3.5 times more likely to die from COVID than the white British group.

column1: Even when factoring in vaccine status and other relevant variables
column2: they were still 1.2 times more likely to die from COVID.

column1: Remaining unexplained risk may be attributable to factors that we have not been able to account for in the analysis
column2: the research said.

column1: The Cabinet Office Race Disparity Unit has explored the evidence around COVID-19 risk factors
column2: but further work is needed to increase our knowledge and understanding of the possible mechanisms underlying this unexplained risk.""

column1: This does not suggest the vaccine is not effective within these groups but means differences in vaccination coverage does not explain the observed differences in mortality risk.
Vaccines explain mortality in other groups
However
column2: the study also found vaccine uptake did explain a large part of the differences in mortality between other ethnic groups.

column1: The rate of death involving COVID-19 has been higher for almost all ethnic minority groups throughout the pandemic
column2: and this was seen again during the third wave
column3: from 13 June 2021 onwards.

column1: While factors - such as geography and age - explained some of the excess risk
column2: differences in vaccine uptake explain the rest.

column1: For example
column2: men and women from black Caribbean and black Caribbean backgrounds were seen to be at a higher risk from COVID - two groups with the lowest vaccination rates among those aged over 50.

column1: But adjusting for vaccination status (alongside other factors) eliminated the excess risk for these groups and suggested they were at no greater risk than the white British population.
Vahé Nafilyan
column2: senior statistician at the ONS
column3: said: ""Today's analysis shows that since the vaccination programme began
column4: the risk of death from COVID-19 has continued to be higher in most ethnic minority groups than in the white British ethnic group.

column1: As already highlighted in our analyses of earlier periods
column2: these differences in mortality are largely explained by socio-demographic and economic factors and health.

column1: For the first time
column2: we show that the lower vaccination coverage in some ethnic groups also contributes to the elevated risk of COVID-19 death
column3: particularly in the black African and black Caribbean groups.""

column21: 'street'];"The much-anticipated Sue Gray report into alleged COVID breaches inside Downing Street could prove damning for Boris Johnson - but the police inquiry that follows will be even more wide-reaching.

column1: Met Police Commissioner Dame Cressida Dick revealed on Tuesday her force has launched a probe into ""a number of events that took place at Downing Street and Whitehall in the last two years in relation to potential breaches of COVID-19 regulations"".
She said the decision to launch a criminal investigation came amid ""deep public concern"" about the allegations in recent weeks and after information was handed to the force by the Cabinet Office.
Johnson to decide how much of Partygate report is made public - follow live politics updates
Please use Chrome browser for a more accessible video player 1:01 Met launches investigation into a number of Downing Street events
Why is the Met now investigating?
Advertisement
The police decided to investigate on Sunday
column2: according to The Times
column3: after receiving evidence from Sue Gray's Cabinet Office team of potential criminal breaches.

column1: Dame Cressida explained that although police guidance has been to not investigate potential COVID breaches ""long after they are said to have taken place""
column2: three key criteria for those ""serious"" and ""most flagrant"" allegations that should be probed had been met.

column1: They are:
evidence that those involved knew or ought to have known they were committing an offence
that by not investigating it would significantly undermine the legitimacy of the law
that there is little ambiguity over the absence of any reasonable defence
Who is leading it?
The Met inquiry will be carried out by detectives from the force's Special Enquiries Team
column2: which specialises in sensitive cases and will be overseen by senior management.

column1: It will be led by Jane Connors
column2: the force's deputy assistant commissioner and lead for COVID enforcement.

column1: Image: Met Police Deputy Assistant Commissioner Jane Connors
A Scotland Yard source described her to the Telegraph as the ""epitome of no nonsense"".
She played a key role in the strategic response to the 2017 Westminster terror attack and has been in charge of handling the Extinction Rebellion protests that have crippled parts of London.
How is it different to the Gray inquiry?
The police have much wider-reaching powers than Sue Gray and the Cabinet Office.
Reports have claimed that some Downing Street staff have been reluctant to give evidence to the Gray inquiry
column2: but they would have to if asked to by detectives.

column1: The Met can interview both potential organisers and guests of any events and compel them to submit phone records and other material.
They are still allowed to answer 'no comment'
column2: however.

column1: Detectives already have access to CCTV footage from outside Downing Street and other government buildings and any notes or reports made by protection officers guarding them.
But they could ask for further footage to track people's movements.
Please use Chrome browser for a more accessible video player 1:44 Joshua Rozenberg gives his take on the scope of the Met inquiry
What could the punishment be?
The Coronavirus Act 2020 meant police could issue fixed penalty notices (FPNs) to anyone breaking the rules.
Initially this meant a £60 fine
column2: doubling each time for repeat offences. People had 28 days to pay or they risked being arrested or summoned to court.

column1: On 13 May 2020
column2: this was increased to £100 and in September to £200 - reduced to £100 if paid within 14 days
column3: and doubling up to £6

column1: In August 2020 the law also changed so that organisers of large events of 30 people or more could be fined up to £10
Those who attended gatherings of at least 15 people risked an £800 maximum fine.
Image: A police officer reminds people of COVID rules in Brighton in May 2020
Human rights barrister Adam Wagner told Sky News that any potential fine will depend on what the law was at the time of an alleged offence.
He added that officials could also be prosecuted for misconduct in public office - not just under the COVID act - ""if their conduct was in breach of public trust and was serious enough"".
But legal commentator Joshua Rozenberg said that being a common law offence
column2: prosecution guidance on misconduct in public office is ""terribly vague and unclear"".

column1: The Crown Prosecution Service would need to offer independent advice to the police on this
column2: he told Sky News.

column1: What will it cover?
Dame Cressida refused to reveal which alleged events could be included in the investigation
column2: but said that FPNs ""will not be issued in every instance and to every person"".

column1: Here we look at which events the Met investigation could cover and what the rules were at the time.
A photo published by The Guardian shows Boris Johnson
column2: his wife Carrie
column3: principal private secretary Martin Reynolds and then-special adviser Dominic Cummings in the Downing Street garden.

column1: Former health secretary Matt Hancock was also reported to be there
column2: alongside around 20 other staff.

column1: Sources claim they drank wine and ate food and the prime minister was there for 15 minutes when he said his colleagues deserved a drink for ""beating back coronavirus"".
What were the rules?
Only two people were allowed to socialise with each other - only outdoors - not in private gardens - and providing social distancing was maintained.
In England FPNs were set at £100.

An email obtained by ITV News showed that the PM's principal private secretary Martin Reynolds emailed staff on 20 May 2020 inviting them to ""some socially distanced drinks in the No 10 garden"" that evening.
It read: ""Hi all
column2: after what has been an incredibly busy period we thought it would be nice to make the most of the lovely weather and have some socially distanced drinks in the No 10 garden this evening. Please join us from 6pm and bring your own booze!""

column1: Image: Principal Private Secretary to Boris Johnson
column2: Martin Reynolds. Pic: UK Government

column1: Mr Johnson admitted he attended the drinks at around 6pm and stayed for 25 minutes to thank staff - 40 of which are believed to have been there.
He later said he ""believed implicitly"" it was a work event.
What were the rules?
The same rules on meeting one other person outside applied at this point
column2: with £100 fines doubling for repeat offences.

From 1 June 2020 groups of six people were allowed to meet outdoors
column2: including in private gardens

London was still in Tier 3 COVID restrictions

column17: Pamela Anderson had Tommy Lee's name tattooed on her ring finger

column1: It was February 1995 when the nuptials took place
column2: the ultimate Baywatch babe swapping her famous red swimsuit for a white string bikini to marry the Motley Crue rocker on a beach in Cancun
column3: Mexico.

column1: Anderson and Lee very quickly became a 1990s tabloid dream; the Playboy pin-up and the tattooed bad boy
column2: a couple who couldn't keep their hands off each other - and weren't afraid to let people (journalists and photographers included) know about it.

Despite the couple's efforts to curtail it once they found it was gone
column2: the tape snowballed. Coinciding with the early days of the internet
column3: the footage went from underground bootleg-VHS curiosity to full-blown global headline-maker
column4: the first celebrity sex tape to go viral.

column1: When sex tapes featuring Paris Hilton and Kim Kardashian came out in later years
column2: the narrative was the same: the women were laughed at

column6: the Kim Kardashian sex tape; in Hilton and Kardashian's cases
column7: do you even remember the names of the men involved? (Bizarrely
column9: who made the tape with Hilton

column1: Years later
column2: the subject of her own tape inevitably comes up whenever Anderson is interviewed. She has never watched it
column3: never made any money off it herself - despite others reportedly making millions - she tells interviewers
column4: sometimes laughing off their jokes about it. She was an actress and model who had posed naked and spoken openly about her sex life; for years

column1: The leaking of a tape like this now would be considered revenge porn. Watching some of those clips in 2022 brings about a similar sense of unease evoked by the footage of inappropriate questioning in old Britney Spears interviews
column2: which came to the fore as her conservatorship fight made headlines last year.

column1: Post #MeToo
column2: the world views stories such as this very differently now. And yet
column3: Anderson and Lee's story is being dramatised in the new series Pam & Tommy

Anderson has had no involvement in the series. Which begs the question: why is the story being retold for entertainment

column1: James

column3: has been transformed beyond recognition to become the all-American (well
column5: she has spoken of the ""misogyny"" Anderson was faced with and how women have always been held to much higher standards than men.

column1: But after making tabloid headlines herself in 2020
column2: when she was linked to her married The Pursuit Of Love co-star Dominic West
column3: she must know all too well what it is like having your personal life gossiped about by the world.

column1: Director Craig Gillespie
column2: known for films including I

column5: to shine a spotlight on how Anderson and Lee (to a much lesser extent)
column6: were treated at the time and present the story in ""a much kinder"" way.

column1: [People] don't realise what victims they were
column2: he tells Sky News. ""This was a deeply personal tape. It wasn't [just] a sex tape

column4: like all of their relationship and some beautiful moments and happened to have [a few] minutes of explicit stuff on there that was in a safe

column1: Image: Director Craig Gillespie says he hopes the show changes the narrative of the story from the misogyny of the 1990s
On Anderson not being involved

column4: so I thought it was something that was a real opportunity to change the narrative and the perspective of what happened back then... Looking at it through today's lens was a really unique opportunity.""

column1: Gillespie also says Anderson and Lee's story ""colliding"" with the rise of the internet makes for a ""powerful commentary"" on society and how the way we consume news and information has changed.
[It was] like the beginning of this obsession with the internet and how we're so complicit. It's like there's no accountability for how we consume this

column19: 'womans'];"Any changes to a woman's period following a COVID-19 vaccine are ""small"" and go on to ""quickly reverse""

column1: More than 36
column2: 000 women reported changes to their periods to the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) following a jab.

column1: Writing in The BMJ - formerly known as the British Medical Journal - Dr Victoria Male
column2: a lecturer in reproductive immunology at Imperial College London
column3: said the latest evidence showed changes to cycles are ""limited but reassuring"".

column1: Dr Male also highlighted that periods can vary naturally.
She drew attention to a study carried out in the US which showed the first dose of a vaccine was not linked to a change in timing of a woman's next period.
Advertisement
After a second dose
column2: there was an average delay of 0.45 days.

column1: The greatest changes were faced by women who had two doses of a vaccine within one cycle
column2: who faced an average delay of 2.32 days.

column1: This scenario is unlikely in the UK
column2: as longer periods between jabs are advised.

column1: The study found that any change in length to someone's cycle returned to normal after a couple of months.
A separate study from Norway asked women about changes to the periods both before and after vaccination.
Some 38% of women reported changes after getting a first dose.
The study did identify heavier than normal bleeding as the change most associated with vaccination.
Follow the Daily podcast on Apple Podcasts
column2: Google Podcasts
column3: Spotify

column1: Dr Male wrote: ""The findings from both these studies are reassuring: changes to the menstrual cycle do occur following vaccination
column2: but they are small compared with natural variation and quickly reverse.""

column1: She added: ""The MHRA says that current evidence does not support a link between changes to menstrual periods and COVID vaccination in the UK
column2: and it continues to advise that anyone noticing a change to their periods that persists over several of cycles
column3: or who has any new vaginal bleeding after the menopause
column4: be treated according to the usual clinical pathways.""";https://web.archive.org/web/20220127111004/http://news.sky.com/story/covid-19-changes-to-periods-from-coronavirus-vaccines-small-and-quickly-reverse-says-expert-12525750;

column1: In our first few days in Herat
column2: we've met whole families who've sold their kidneys so they can eat.

column1: In one case
column2: three brothers and their two sisters told us they flogged their organs for around £1
column3: 150 a piece to buy food for the rest of the family.

column1: We've sat with a mother grieving over her toddler who starved to death. We've heard multiple parents tell us how they're now resorting to selling their children.
Yes
column2: selling them.

column1: Image: A close up of one man's kidney operation scar. Pic: Chris Cunningham
Image: Men show us their kidney operation scars. Pic: Chris Cunningham
And we've spoken to emotional doctors who tell us they can't afford even the dressings for infected wounds nor the basic tools to do life-saving operations.
This is Afghanistan post-pull out for foreign troops. This is the country in which a coalition of nations spent 20 years
column2: shelling out billions of dollars to ""rebuild it"".

column1: This is the nation where so many lives were sacrificed - thousands - both foreign troops and ordinary Afghans.
Image: One woman shows the scar from surgery to remove a kidney
This is the part of the world which the United Nations now says is fast becoming the centre of the globe's worst humanitarian disaster.
Afghanistan was poor and in difficulties before the chaotic withdrawal of foreign troops last August.
Now
column2: with the Taliban in power and the rest of the world still not officially recognising the legitimacy of their government
column3: it's the Afghan people who're having to resort to ever more extreme measures to survive.

column1: Please use Chrome browser for a more accessible video player 5:26 Who are the Taliban
The desperation in communities
In a small village community outside Herat
column2: we saw the desperation and desolation of poverty.

column1: We're concealing the exact location of the village and protecting the identities of all the villagers who spoke to us for their own safety. Our arrival along with the village elder prompted streams of people to come out of their mud houses and tents.
Within minutes
column2: old women were thrusting medical documents into our hands pleading with us for help while mothers clutching babies begged us for food.

column1: Image: The humanitarian situation is getting truly desperate for millions of Afghans. Pic: Chris Cunningham

Rows of people of varying ages and with a variety of chronic diseases and disabilities were lined up for us to see - each one with a relative urging us to somehow deliver some hope and relief to them.
This area seems to us utterly barren
column2: with no water or shrubbery for miles around. In many cases the only currency these families have is their organs - and with so many having already resorted to selling them
column3: it's now their young who're being put on the market.

column1: Read more: UN seeks record $5bn in aid to prevent Afghanistan 'suffering'
We spoke to a mother and father who've both sold their kidneys.
All they'd got left to sell now was one of their eight children - so they were thinking the unthinkable. The 25-year-old mother told us: ""About six months ago
column2: my three-year-old son died of hunger. I can't see them all lose their lives... at least this way
column3: someone else will feed them.""

column1: Image: Alex Crawford talks to mother and father who have already sold their kidneys and are now thinking of selling a child because their situation is so desperate. Pic: Chris Cunningham

Her voice was breaking with emotion as she told us. Her husband told us he hadn't yet decided which child to sell but such was their desperation he would sell the child off for less than the price of his kidney.
We have nothing left to sell
column2: he said. ""We have to sell our children now and I'm prepared to do this for even 20
column3: 000 Afghanis (about £150 or $200). I can't go to sleep every night with them crying that they are hungry.""

column1: Taliban say it is a 'myth'
The Taliban says this is all a Western myth
column2: dreamed up by evil
column3: dishonest Western media to discredit them.

column1: They also say all girls in the country are in education
column2: that schools and universities are all open and they're not rounding up female activists or carrying out vendettas against those who worked with the foreign troops once stationed here for two decades.

column1: Image: Taliban at a checkpoint. Pic: Chris Cunningham
The Taliban appear to have ""alternative facts"" to what many others are living through on the ground in Afghanistan.

The rapid withdrawal of foreign troops in August saw the Taliban sweep into power. The international community imposed sanctions and billions of dollars-worth of assets were frozen in overseas bank accounts
column2: mostly American.

column1: It's meant the economy has virtually collapsed with few jobs and very little hard currency available for ordinary Afghans.
The lack of worldwide recognition of the Taliban government has meant a country which was previously almost wholly dependent on foreign aid has seen that all but dry up.
Please use Chrome browser for a more accessible video player 3:41 'I was so scared': Taliban's crackdown on women
Read more: Taliban's crackdown against women exposed
And respect for women's' rights has repeatedly been cited by global donors as a condition for restoring that aid.
But the dilemma for the international community is trying to balance the pressure exerted on the Taliban to respect human rights
column2: against the obvious and deepening suffering of the Afghan people.

column1: The little aid which is seeping in is not nearly adequate for the millions who need it.
Hospitals run out of treatments
So
column2: in the Herat Regional Hospital in Herat City
column3: we found doctors like Dr Mohammad Aqel Halimee emotional and tearful over not even having enough dressings to bandage his young patients in the children's ward of the hospital's burns unit.

column1: Image: Doctor Mohammad Aqel Halimee from Herat Hospital burns unit talks to Alex Crawford. Pic: Chris Cunningham
Many have badly infected injuries caused by deep burns from open fires which families use to try to keep warm in mid-winter.
But with most parents unable to pay for the medicines or bandages
column2: never mind expensive surgeries
column3: their children are often sent home to die.

column1: Dr Aqel said the medics suffer badly from the emotional toll taken on them.
I have a bad sensation
column2: he said. ""Because (it's all down to the) lack of materials... I have the ability to treat them but lack of materials and bandages means I can't help them.""

column1: Image: A girl called Aisha at the burns unit of Herat hospital
column2: who is at risk of dying if she cannot get medical supplies. Pic: Chris Cunningham

column1: Many kidney buyers from across border
In the village community on the outskirts of Herat city
column2: I was allowed into a room to see a group of women who'd all sold their kidneys.

column1: In this highly conservative society
column2: they wouldn't even show their faces in public
column3: never mind their bare midriffs - but they allowed me to film them so long as their faces weren't shown.

column1: Many of them were still teenagers or in their early twenties and already had multiple children. I noticed a number of them were pregnant again.

But there's a lucrative kidney trade in this area with the region's proximity to the Iranian border and many of the buyers are from across the border - and this extreme poverty has driven more Afghans onto the operating tables to try to wipe out debts and provide food for their families.
Image: A group of women from the same village who have all sold a kidney for money. Pic: Chris Cunningham
Since the Taliban came into power
column2: there's apparently been a clamping down on kidney transplants but our investigations seem to indicate this has just sent the trade deeper underground.

column1: Many were nervous about talking to us about it because of fears over repercussions from the Taliban who are attempting to portray a certain image to the outside world.
'We have no choice'
One teenage mother told us she'd been operated on about a month ago.
The angry
column2: red weal of her scar seemed to back this up.

column1: We have no choice
column2: she said
column3: ""We do this to feed our children.""

column1: Please use Chrome browser for a more accessible video player 3:43 How did the Taliban pay for the takeover?
There are so many of them heading into the city for operations
column2: they complain its driven down the organ price - only 150
column3: 000 Afghanis (£1
column5: 500) for the women compared to earlier payments of 200

column1: The village elder did his best to try to persuade the couple not to sell any of their children
column2: a number of whom were sitting with us listening to this discussion.

column1: And then he turned to us.
I urge the world
column2: please don't leave us alone
column3: he said. ""Stop this tragedy of people selling their children or part of their bodies. Afghanistan needs help.""";https://web.archive.org/web/20220127111004/http://news.sky.com/story/afghanistan-parents-sell-children-and-kidneys-to-feed-starving-families-12525919;

column1: The observation is known as a radio transient

column1: 'Spooky' discovery

It was kind of spooky for an astronomer because there's nothing known in the sky that does that
column2: said Natasha Hurley-Walker
column3: of the International Centre for Radio Astronomy Research at Curtin University
column4: who led the team that made the discovery.

column1: Image: The star icon shows the position of the mysterious repeating transient in the Milky Way
column2: as viewed by Earth

column1: While the occurrences have been seen before - usually as very quick events that flash on and off within seconds or milliseconds or as longer pulses that last days - radio transients had not previously been detected appearing and disappearing over a few hours
column2: Ms Hurley-Walker said.

column1: The team is carrying out more research to figure out what is causing the bursts of energy
column2: but the astronomers think it could be a so-called magnetar
column3: which is a special type of ""dead"" star with an ultra-strong magnetic field.

column1: Ms Hurley-Walker said the prospect of a repeating radio signal in space may cause some to think it could be a dispatch from aliens
column2: but she said the observations spanned a wide range of frequencies - indicating that they have a natural origin.

column1: First discovered by a student
Former undergraduate student at Curtin University
column2: Tyrone O'Doherty
column3: first discovered the object by looking at Milky Way observations from March 2018 and May 2018 and searching for any differences.

column1: He said he hadn't expected to make such a fascinating discovery
column2: telling a news briefing: ""It really feels quite surreal to have found something like this.""

column1: To confirm the discovery
column2: Ms Hurley-Walker sifted through extensive archives stretching back to 2013
column3: to see whether the telescope had picked up any other activity from the object.

column1: She found that it had switched on in the first part of 2018
column2: emitting 71 flashes of radio signals from January until March
column3: before switching off again. As she and her colleagues saw in their own observations
column4: the pulses came at regular intervals.

column1: It's just every 18.18 minutes
column2: like clockwork
column3: she said.

column1: Unleashing further details will require observing the object when it is active again or finding similar objects elsewhere in the Milky Way
column2: Ms Hurley-Walker said.

column1: The team also found that the newly detected object appears to be spinning much more slowly than other magnetars
column2: suggesting it has outlived others that usually last only a few thousand years.

column1: But Ms Hurley-Walker said it could also be an entirely new type of cosmic object that caused the flashes of energy.
Because we didn't expect this kind of radio emission to be possible
column2: the fact that it exists tells us that some kind of extreme physical processes must be happening
column3: she said.

column1: The researchers detailed the finding in a study published this week in the journal Nature.";https://web.archive.org/web/20220127111004/http://news.sky.com/story/milky-way-discovery-as-astronomers-uncover-spooky-spinning-object-unlike-anything-seen-before-12526377;

column17: 'charged'];"A man has been charged by Irish police after a dead body of a pensioner was brought to a post office in an apparent attempt to collect his pension.

column1: It follows the arrest of two men in their 30s yesterday as part of the ongoing investigation into the incident that took place last week.
The second man has been released from custody.
The man who was charged is scheduled to appear before Carlow District Court this morning.
Peadar Doyle
column3: was brought to the post office in Co Carlow last Friday by two men and reportedly carried up to the counter.

column1: Advertisement
When the group approached
column2: a ""concerned staff member enquired about the wellbeing of the man being propped up""
column3: the Irish Times said.

column1: At that point
column2: the two men ""dropped the man and left the post office""
column3: it was reported.

column1: Staff then apparently attended to the man and found he had died.
According to RTE
column2: a man initially called into the post office on Staplestown Road in Carlow town to collect a pension on behalf of an elderly man.

column1: But he was reportedly told that the recipient had to be present
column2: and two men arrived a short time later with the deceased.

column1: No money was handed over
column2: the Irish Independent said.

column1: Earlier this week
column2: a man named Declan Haughney admitted to the Irish Mirror that he was one of the men who took Mr Doyle
column3: apparently his uncle
column5: but insisted he had not realised he had died.

column1: He claimed he and another man took Mr Doyle on a five-minute walk from his home on Pollerton Road
column2: Carlow
column3: to collect his pension last Friday morning.

column1: The 40-year-old said he had lived with his uncle throughout his life and believes he may have died on the way to Hosey's post office on Staplestown Road.
He said he and another man linked arms with him and dragged him to the post office.
He was walking like normal and then I reckon he died
column2: he said
column3: adding that Mr Doyle started ""dragging his heels"" at one point.

column1: We were grand like then all of a sudden he started going all slumpy
column2: he said.

column1: We thought nothing of it because Peadar had had heart attacks and all.""
The Irish Times previously reported that police believe Mr Doyle died before his body reached the post office at 11am.
Foul play has reportedly been ruled out but a post-mortem was only able to estimate the time of death as some time on Friday morning.

Police have not yet determined whether the retired painter was already dead when taken from the house.";https://web.archive.org/web/20220127122528/https://news.sky.com/story/man-charged-after-dead-body-of-pensioner-brought-to-post-office-in-ireland-12526468;
